sentence: This is the truth: This documentary perfectly captured the experiences of the Marcos and the exploited people
It showed what it is like to live with extensive wealth and how the Marcos regime used it for political power and their self interests
This is a must watch film for those who wish to see the Marcos' perspective on Martial Law and their countless political movements
This documentary shows the truth, through direct interviews with the Marcoses, and it is up to you if you are going to believe it
As John Henry Newman would say: "We can believe what we choose but we are answerable for what we choose to believe

Prescient and illuminating: As I write Ferdinand Marcus junior or 'bong bong' has been elected president of the Philippines, so it's a good time to view this documentary about the Marcos dynasty, its rise, its fall in the peoples revolution of 1986, and the gradual and dramatic rise again of its fortunes; in particular this film focuses on the surprisingly influential, some might say malevolent role that Imelda Marcos played

It's a shocking tale of shameless corruption nepotism cronyism and greed, at the end of which one can only feel saddened for the Filipino people, who have been used abused lied to and robbed over decades by their elite, and still are

Half of todays Filipino voters were not alive for the first Marcos era, but I was there in late 1985 and saw the huge disparity between the rich and poor, and just how hated the Marcos regime was at the time
Sadly all of that now seems to have been forgotten
If you want to know something of the true story of the Marcos 'dynasty' see this fine doc
Privilege matters, Political horror
: Well worth watching
Amazing documentary about privilege and the sociopathic mindset
It's about a narcissistic self serving former first lady abusing her position
The film shines on the ugly politics of the Philippines
Excellent insight into vile monsters
: I love the Philippines, visited many times and my longterm gf is there
The carnage left behind from this disgusting dynasty is there for all to see today in the form of vastly stunted economic growth down to the billions of dollars embezzled by these creatures
This documentary is wonderfully put together but leaves me sad to see a country I am so fond of suffering even today from what these two people did
Her state of mass delusion is clear for all to see in this excellent piece of work
Real life political horror: Horrifically illustrates how a nation's collective memory can be erased in real time and the true limits of democracy in the social media age

Imelda comes across as a complete psychopath with absolutely no perception of reality
This is what happens to you when you drink your own kool-aid folks
In a world where social media can be manipulated to create alternate realities, these historical revisionists will find it even easier to get away with murder
God help us all

This is of course very irritating
She paints the obvious corrupt opposition as saints

"Perception is Real and the Truth is NOT": With the Marcoses' consistent effort to rewrite history, this documentary reminds us that behind the grandeur and elaborate schemes of the Marcoses are the stories of pain and sorrows of the victims, which are not mere perception but the truth

As Greenfield's style is apparent in the documentary, it did not fail to capture the depressing history of the Philippines under the Marcoses and what may be an apparent future if they were put again into position
The contrasting images presented by Greenfield is a great divider between Perception and Reality
The Kingmaker - Film Review: The Kingmaker is a documentary written and directed by Lauren Greenfield

The film follows the political career of Imelda Marcos from the start of her political career with her husband Ferdinand Marcos, the fall of their power and exhile to Hawaii, and then their resurgence after her husbands death and rise of the political career of her children - especially her son Bongbong Marcos
This film does a good job of contrasting the story Imelda portrays versus the reality of those under her rule
Imelda will say how great her husbands reign was
Then you have individuals speak about the atrocities of what occurred
I found the film very informative as someone who did not know about the subject matter going in
I also appreciated how the film showed the current scene of the Philippines with Bongbong running for Vice-President (and who is President as I write this 6 years after the film came out)
Overall, I think this is a worthwhile watch to learn about the history of the Philippines political dynasty from 1965 - 1986, and then again around 2016
Uncovering the Fantasy World of the Marcoses: Brilliant documentary
It shows how much you can do with money; it can turn lies to history
An eye opener: Highly recommend this
Like her or loathe her you can't deny the blatant pesos for politics
Watching Marcos hand out wads of cash to kids in a hospital ward in front of the cameras was as cynical as it was sickening
I've never paid much (read: any) attention to Filipino politics but will be following along the 2022 election with interest
Dark truths are there if your eyes are open: This is an incredibly well put together documentary

Imelda Marcos doesn't exactly shoot herself in the foot - she is too smart to do that, but you nonetheless get to see the realities she so flagrantly ignores whilst living in her self made fantasy world
How many billions has this power crazed matriarch squirreled away in 140 countries across the world
There are only 8 and a bit billion people on the planet and handing each one a single dollar might seem like generosity but this very much hides the manipulations of the Marcos clan
We note other world leaders seem to be in the same exclusive club as this gurning despot
Lord help us all
Outstanding and riveting documentary: "The Kingmaker" (2019 release; 100 min
) is a documentary about the life and times of Imelda Marcos, erstwhile First Lady of the Philippines (1965-1986)
As the movie opens, we are in "Manile, 2014", and Imelda is visiting the old neighborhood (the Presidential Palace)
"I miss the clout of being First Lady", she laments, while wondering if her appearance and make-up for the interview is ok
We then go back in time, as we look at her very modest upbringing until she catches the eye of Ferdinand Marcos while in a beauty contest
Before we know it, they marry and Marcos vies to become President of the Philippines
At this point we are 10 min
into the documentary
Couple of comments: this is the latest documentary from writer-director Lauren Greenfield, best known for her 2012 documentary "The Queen of Versailles"

Here she seemingly gets unfettered access to Imelda and her entourage, and she lets Imelda tell her side of the story, one in which of course Imelda is but a shining bright star in the darkness that is the Filipino sea of poverty
The great thing is that Greenfield doesn't have to "manufacture" anything: Imelda does it for her

Greenfield of course give ample screen time to opposing views, including survivirs of the Martial Lawera (1972-1980), during which torturing was rampant, And oh, lest we forget: the Marcoses stole an estimated $8-10 billion (with a "b") while in office
And if all of this isn't enough, Greenfield follows the Vice Predential election campaign in 2015-16 of Bongbong Marcos (son of Imelda), which itself becomes as revelating as anyting (just watch
When confronted with issues of "ill-gotten wealth", Imelda simply shrugs it off (as does Bongbong)
"Perception is real, and the truth is not", she states as a matter of fact
Hmmm, where have we heard this elsewhere in recent times
Bottom line: "The Kingmaker" is an oustanding and riveting documentar, period
"The Kingmaker" premiered on Showtime in 2019, which I somehow missed, but I recently caught it on Showtime on Demand and it is available on other VOD platforms too
If you have any interest in "lifestyles of the rich and famous", or how depots fleece an entire country for decades, I'd readily suggest you check this out, and draw your own conclusion
insight in something unseen: Interesting story about something i knew nothing about

The tide is changing this time because of the emergence of young voters gearing towards the new wave of politicians but its harder to fight for votes knowing that the machinery handling them is leaning towards the Marcoses

It’s easy to write about this film, and also extremely difficult
Personally, I’d rather talk about the difficult part
Writing an “easy” review simply means pointing out how the resurgence of authoritarian legacies is happening everywhere, and how films like this serve as warnings to the public
That’s a straightforward approach
But I can’t shake the feeling that if we rely solely on films to revive fear of past atrocities, the effect may actually backfire
Throwing all the past horrors…

“Perception is real, the truth is not”I watched this documentary way back on December 25, 2022—the same year when Ferdinand Marcos Jr
, the son of the late dictator, won the presidential election
During that time, I was still grieving (and honestly, I still am) over the fact that despite his family’s wickedness, despite their crimes against the Filipino people—his son still managed to win
I was new to these things back then, and English was still a challenge for me
But when I heard Imelda Marcos utter those words, my jaw dropped
Every word that comes out of this woman’s mouth is either a lie, arrogance, delusion, or fabrication
It’s ironic that they gave her the benefit of the doubt, but it turns out to be a reason for us to hate her even more
As the saying goes, you can catch a fish by its mouth—and in this case, her words alone expose how filthy, hideous, and wicked she is
Although I was still new to in-depth politics during that time, I was shocked by how she spoke about some of the worst politicians of her era with such pride and admiration
Not to mention how rich she became, not through hard work or service, but through theft disguised as glamour
She’s delusional
You’re not mothering—Imelda, you’re manipulating

Now this might strike some viewers as harsh, but I believe everyone involved in this story should die

What I love the most about Lauren Greenfield’s films is that she lets her subject and the material speak so clearly that you can understand everything that she’s implying
The film opens up with Mrs
Marcos driving through an impoverished street in the Philippines, looking sorrowful covered in designer clothing and pieces of jewelry that could probably remake the entire neighborhood
She takes out her wallet and hands out 50 pesos to each of the residents who clamor to her window once they see who she is and what she has in her hands
Her hands move with the precision of a Coin-o-matic, only dispersing one crisp bill per person
This is all she can manage to provide and all she thinks the deserve
The film documents the atrocities, glamour, abuses, and scandal of the Marcos regime while covering Bong Bong Marcos’s bid for vice president
The parallels to America’s current fascist regime are apparent
The image of Mrs
Marcos that emerges is that she never grew out of the child who was abandoned by her mother and was not taught the true meaning of love

“Perception is real and the truth is not,” words from a woman who was essentially the face of the darkest moments in Filipino history
This documentary was not just meant to inform the people; it was a warning a warning that the sins of the past would come back to haunt the Filipino people, and they have
In recent months, the Philippines has been marred by controversies involving ghost projects and corrupt officials
Yet, after speaking with many people about this matter, one question always prevails: How
How did the corruption, plunder, and blatant theft from the Filipino people become so severe
Upon watching this, the answer became clear as day: it is because we allowed those who started the problem to get away with it
We, as Filipinos, glorified the rich and powerful, while the poor who fought back were treated as criminals
The rich became gods, the supposed benefactors of the poor, when in truth, what they gave was only a fraction of what they had stolen
The Marcoses became the blueprint of Philippine corruption today
They set the rules on how to plunder the people
To fix this issue, we must first hold accountable those who began it in the first place
Democracy no longer truly exists in the Philippines, for it has long been the government against the people ever since the Marcoses were allowed back into the political landscape
Forgetting the past horrors, terrors, and sins has only allowed history to repeat itself
It may not always be under the same name or family, but it is carried out in the same way
If we want change, we must believe that it is not a question of when but of how
We must commit to a long-term process of change, not fall for empty promises
A nation cannot be built in a day, and solutions to systemic issues will never materialize in just a few years
Despite all this, I remain optimistic that these recent issues of corruption will open the eyes of those who were once blinded by words and false promises
The Filipino people should no longer be bound by biased perceptions; we are slowly beginning to see the truth
We are being played and I hope these events will finally serve as the catalyst for change: a change in governance, a change in mentality, and a change for the betterment of the Philippines

"Now is what's important, so the past is past
There are so many things in the past that we should forget
In fact, it's no longer there
"The first time I saw this documentary was in early-2020
I was in the living room with my parents, my tita and my lola; they were all alive during Martial Law
I recall how annoyed my family were as Imelda talked about her side of the story and how "sad" it was to see the country turn their backs on the Marcoses
Even then, perhaps due in part to my family's influence, I was heavily critical of the Marcoses and their claims, as well as the rhetoric of then-president Rodrigo Duterte

This was months before the pandemic that was poorly addressed by Duterte's administration, three years before Bongbong would be elected straight to the presidential seat, and six years before Duterte would be charged with crimes against humanity by the ICC and sent to the Hague while his followers claimed that he was "unjustly arrested"
I love the way that this documentary was shot

The juxtaposition of the lavish Marcos spendings with the effects they have had on the lowest sectors of society do a good job at providing insight into the sheer amount of ill-gotten wealth they have procured over the years
The intimate interviews we get from this documentary are also a huge highlight for me
It makes me wonder how the crew were able to get so many high-profile people for this documentary
In retrospect, it is almost horrible foreshadowing to see all this talk of BBM's race to vice presidency when he is currently our president
It's like he got what he wanted and more
What does it say about us as a country that we are willing to let the son of a dictator and kleptocrat, as well as their family, back into power
Or rather, what does it say about our education systems and efforts to retain the facts of the Martial Law era
To still see the Marcos family in power shows that they really did essentially get away almost scot-free
At this point in time, it is more imperative than ever to never forget what their dynasty has done to our country, and to never again repeat the mistakes of the past
I am thankful that from a young age, my family's stories and experiences living under the Marcos regime have been instilled in me
I am thankful that I have people in my life to make sure that I remember our history

i am torn between two things: on the one hand, my background in Psychology has me looking at everything as a case study, and what is more interesting than a powerful family who built their fortune and influence on violence
on the other hand, was it necessary to screen this in the middle of a then-impending (now real) Marcos Jr

presidency, and expect a divided nation to discern for themselves when things could be so easily taken out of context–especially those under the false illusion of the absolute goodness of the Marcoses, looking only for what will reinforce their perceived truths
i had faced the dilemma of being in the middle of it all, as at that time i was working in an artist collective that organized an annual film festival, which had this at the center of the programming
we also organized screenings and talkbacks in different areas in the country, but make no mistake: it was an ethical dilemma for everyone involved
how will it live beyond its 2-3 year festival circuit lifespan
how will it be viewed as it is, a decade later, without the talkback discussions and with all of the Martial Law survivors gone
there are thousands, if not millions, of stories that are yet to be told
in my hometown i can recall a few quite easily, with the remnants of the dictatorship still very much alive in every corner of our island
it does not help that Imelda is centered in this narrative
it does not help that the victims and survivors in the documentary felt more like a testament to the power of the Marcos family than the actual holders of this historical narrative
this should not have been the story of Imelda but the story of the Filipino people who have fought against the seemingly immovable force of the dictatorship
this should have been a portrait of the force that moved against them and carved out a victory

i respect the director's focus on cinematic monographs, but at the end of the election cycle that decided a Marcos presidency, we got the answer to the ethical dilemma: no, this film did not move the needle towards the downfall of the Marcos family like we hoped it would

they are back in the highest seat of power, and all we have is a humanized portrait of Imelda and an intellectual discourse that we pass back and forth until it is worn and tired, while the rest of our people survive on scraps after the Marcoses took everything they could

Portrait of one of the most irresponsible politicians you can imagine
Imeldas husband Ferdinand Marcos was democratically elected in 1962 and declared martial law in 1972
Freedom of the press was abolished and all opposition was nipped in the bud
The couple enriched themselves privately from the tax revenue and have been declared as secondary corrupt government by Transparency International at the time
In 1983, unknown killers shot the opposition politician Benigno Aquino at Manila airport, which led to increasing resistance among the population
When Corazon Aquino stood for election in 1986, Marcos had the results manipulated and declared himself the winner
Because of unrest among the population, the Marcos family had to flee - to the USA, where they lived in a palatial house in Hawaii with a good state pension

Imelda continued to claim that her husband was the Philippines' best leader, despite the couple's embezzlement of billions of US dollars (they believed the money belonged to them as leaders of the country
She returned to the Philippines in 1991 and received a seat in the House of Representatives there
She campaigned (successfully
) for her son, who has been President of the Philippines since 2022
It is just as incomprehensible how it happens that Imelda is repeatedly acquitted in the (Philippine) courts
Imelda was willing to be interviewed for the documentary
The woman clearly lives in a parallel reality in which she was the kind mother of Filipinos and always did everything for the good of her country
At the same time, people who knew her talk about her blatant spending: She bought several houses in NYC and founded a small safari park on a supposedly uninhabited island
The 250 families who lived there were simply expelled
This park still existed in 2019, but has now become quite run down due to a lack of funding
The residents who have since returned are having a hard time dealing with the zebras and giraffes that are eating away at their gardens

I generally try to approach documentaries with some degree of neutrality
But how can you do that with Imelda Marcos
In her introduction, she seems like a silly, unassuming old lady sitting in her gilded home and her many shoes, handing out pesos to street children with an air of supreme disinterest
Lauren Greenfield paints a complex portrait, peeling back the layers to reveal a dangerous, intelligent and manipulative figure
Greenfield and her editor keep the film's pulse steady, combatting each of Imelda's increasingly ridiculous lies with evidence to the contrary without feeling sequential
I couldn't believe my ears when she said that martial law was the best time for human rights
I found it difficult to watch
Maybe that's because of my personal histories
Watching Ferdinand Marcos' body be interred at Libingan ng mga Bayani, where my grandfather is buried, left a pit in my stomach
Hearing the testimonies of anti-Marcos activists was devastating

And knowing that I have relatives, including my mother, who remain vocal loyalists and direct victims of the disinformation and whitewashing campaigns that are at the center of this film was another gut punch
The film was completed in 2019 and leaves off on Leni Robredo's victory over BBM in the VP election
It seems that democracy prevailed, and presents like a cautionary tale of the Marcoses; of what can be done when political dynasties are left unchecked with power and influence
As if Greenfield is wagging her finger saying, "don't do what the Filipinos did
" But listening to BBM ramble about stolen elections a full four years before Trump sent a chill down my spine
The propaganda and historical revisionism
The cult of personality
The militarization of the police
It's extra-haunting to see this in 2024, knowing that my family's motherland is under the thumb of the Marcoses again
Well-made, prescient and powerful

The film was captivating, concerning, and strange, but it's also more curious to watch in 2023, after the Marcos family resumed control of the Filipino government last year (via son Bongbong, who appears here)
So much feels telegraphed in hindsight when they get to talking about Bongbong and his then-Vice President campaign

I have no idea if this film gained exposure over there or not, and it looks like the Marcoses had traction there regardless, but I can't help but wonder if putting this lady and her family back in the limelight didn't help gain some eyes, in spite of the film's potential intent

I know it's a different political sphere and culture (though, naturally the US is linked to all of this), but I feel the same way about the exposure of eccentrics like Tr*mp, who never would have made it into office if the media didn't constantly stick a camera on them wondering "What kooky thing will they say next

Imelda Marcos makes amazing documentary filmmaking
Imelda Marcos continues to charm and astonish well into her eighties
It's easy to see how she wielded so much power during her husband's dictatorship
She's so sure of herself - but her language betrays such a lack of self-awareness and shame
Her story, so important to the modern political reality in the Philippines, was so carefully told to cover both the past and the present and how intricately wound they are
Brilliant to interweave the horrors of martial law in the 1970s with the rise of Bongbong (who really comes across as a doltish, boyish, puppet version of his dad) and Duterte (

The Philippines has suffered from such rampant corruption with essentially only the Aquinos offering a brief respite during the presidencies of Cory and Noynoy (the latter of which is featured in this documentary and is quite an eloquent dude)

Seeing the Marcoses claw their way back to power by financing Duterte's campaign and now, of course, with Bongbong as president, I am very troubled for the future of this much abused, but beautiful and resilient country

Binibigyang perspektibo ng dokumentaryo si Imelda Marcos bilang isang ina: a mother to her nation, the first family, and the world
At nakakatakot siya, actually
Kasi nababahiran ng vulnerability at humanity ang pamilyang Marcos, ‘yung parehong pamilyang nanudla, nagnakaw, at nagpahirap sa Pilipinas noong diktaturya ni Marcos Sr
(at patuloy na nagpapahirap sa bansa ngayon sa termino ni Marcos Jr
) Nahuhumanize ‘yung elitist tendencies ni Imelda, najujustify ‘yung paglabag ni Marcos Sr
sa mga karapatang pantao noong Batas Militar, at nacocontextualize ‘yung pagkaganid nila sa kapangyarihan, which, if not viewed critically, ay napakadelikado dahil nakapanlilinlang
Mistulang hindi buo ‘yung pagkukuwento dito sa dokumentaryo kasi halos lahat ng narratives ay galing sa very oppressors na nagpahirap sa Pilipinas
Kulang bilang pambalanse ‘yung critical lens from Martial Law victims na inabuso at tinanggalan ng dignidad ng diktaturyang Marcos

Napakadelikadong uri ng pagsasalaysay muli sa napakasensitibong bahagi ng kasaysayan natin, dahil ang pangunahing mga tagakuwento ay hindi ang mga Pilipino, kundi ‘yung mga nagpapahirap sa mga Pilipino noong panahong iyon

As a social studies teacher, I help students sharpen their critical thinking skills by presenting them facts and figures to guide them in forming their own conclusions
I don't infiltrate to them my own viewpoints, for it may influence their own views
I want my students to form their own opinions and make sure that they are based on facts and empirical evidence
This is exactly how Lauren Greenfield's The Kingmaker presented one of history's most divisive topic
It is a documentary where you see the camera roll and witness the actions speak for themselves
There is no narration, no reenactments, no script, and no talking heads
The main subjects themselves, the Marcos Family (mostly Imelda Marcos) are the ones narrating the entire story
The camera is basically a fly on the wall
Real footages and records from the exact events are also shown
I've also read that the intended direction of the film depends on how interviews went
This means the film does not intentionally gear towards one side of the story only, as both the Marcoses side, the victims, and the witnesses were evenly presented
The result
A compelling story of a true event that almost feels like fiction due to its shocking and unbelievable accounts
It makes you wonder why the Marcoses agree to be the subject of this documentary and how they feel about this

This educational documentary might be a hard watch for some, and I highly advice that the best way to watch this is to have an open mind, without any pre-conceived notions about what the show is about

Was ultimately a more satisfying documentary at capturing not just the delusion of Imelda’s reframing of the martial law years of the Marcos Philippine dictatorship, but the horror of the rise of her children in modern government

Benefited from my having just seen Imelda (2003) and its extensive interview footage giving such clear insight into her mindset in 2003, the further spiral into delusion is even more striking checking back in circa the 2016 election cycle with her renewed confidence seeing her children dominate political discussion juxtaposed with the widening gap between the the rich and poor of the Philippines
The contrast provided by footage from the creation and fall of Imelda’s Calauit Safari Park island is especially fascinating
I am quite ambivalent towards this documentary

It is very well-made however I struggle to see the benefit of giving Imelda Marcos a platform to spout her shameless lies about her husband's totalitarian rule and juxtaposing it with the objective truth of history while somewhat giving off the impression that both outlooks are equal in their merit
Apparently some Marcos apologists enjoyed this movie because of that
Still, I can sort of see the value of this work as an educational resource for the perspective of a foreigner wishing to know more about the history of this corrupt, kleptocratic family
As a Filipino however, the way the documentary presents itself just rubs me the wrong way

Nonetheless, I commend the documentary's objective of educating foreigners about the dire situation here in the Philippines where thieves are worshipped as idols and the corrupt elite manage to evade justice at every turn

Probably one of the most effective parts of the documentary
Watching the documentary, I am simply in disbelief that the side of the Marcos family here was supposed to be painted as if they were actually something good that happened to the Philippines

When in fact, watching this whole documentary, I just learned even more about the atrocious things they have done and thus have manifested even greater anger towards their name and family—naïvely thinking that I already knew enough about their history and was also already angry enough back then
I have to say though that the documentary shows more than simply just the story of the Marcos family and their history
After watching it, I now have realized for sure as well that the Filipino people are too forgiving, too forgetful, and too naïve

And to back that statement up, with no better proof to be given, other than that their family has already been back in power with another Marcos being the president for more than a year now as of the writing of this review
Which is all just really sad to think about—that this is the reality we're living with right now as Filipinos
It was certainly all kinds of emotions that I have felt watching this documentary
With some of it being that of utter disgust towards the Marcos family, our politics, and overall just feeling really bad for our fellow Filipinos
We truly did not deserve any of this or do we deserve yet another Marcos being back in power for that matter
The Marcos family are not even good nor wise politicians in the first place, for they did and were doing much of the atrocious stuff in broad daylight
They were just lucky they were able to prey on the fragility of the Filipino people when it comes to being politically aware
Which is yet another lengthy and very nuanced topic that deserves its separate discussion if I wanted to give it proper justice
But welp, that's the simple gist of it
The Filipino people are naïve, and that naïvety of ours is so easily preyed upon by these people in power
I can only wish and hope that we'll soon know better as a country and as the citizens of it
Anyhow, I do think that this documentary is a must watch, for better or for worse especially for us Filipinos

Just be sure to watch it with an open mind, because you are sure to be taken for quite the ride throughout, and maybe after it—you'll come out with newfound insights regarding this very important and especially relevant point of history in our country

Imelda Marcos said at one point in the documentary that, "Perception is real, and the truth is not" but I will argue that no matter how our perception wants to change the truth, or perceive that something is the truth instead of the other—that the truth of this controversial point of our history and the truth of the revolting history of their family—will continue to exist despite efforts of trying to perceive them the other way to bring upon a new narrative
We, the people that do remember and know will never dare to erase and forget it
#NeverForget & #NeverAgain
I understand why some people are morally opposed to Imelda being documented like this

However, I think it clearly shows how she and Ferdinand were able to gain and keep control in the Philippines before martial law and ward off opposition during it, besides just the killing (which is very bad)
It also is important because clearly, people bought into her mirage again when Bongbong was elected
So if we can see her in a complete light like this, we can hopefully learn how to recognize players like Imelda and avoid getting roped in ourselves

" The legacy of the Marcos family is one of plunder and terror, charity (or "projects" as Imelda calls it) is merely a tool of reputation laundering
That shows clearly in this film
Imelda Marcos is a narcissistic thieving tyrant who probably should not have been given a nearly unfettered platform in this film
She desperately wants to be seen as a benevolent dowager, the "Mother of the Country," but she is nothing but a ruthless political animal
Imelda's positioning of herself as a Mother of the Country figure is grotesque
"This government is soulless," she laments after robotically handing out money to sick children
(I rewound multiple times to try and see if she actually touched any of the downtrodden or if they exist as just mere props for her

It's bizarre, infruriating even, to watch this in 2023 knowing that the Marcos family has returned to power following her son's election
A disheartening cycle continues, "Mother" awakens once more

The bet of this movie is that giving extensive space for Imelda and Bong Bong to tell their whitewashed version of Filipino history is worth it, if paired with counterpoints from the likes of Noynoy Aquino, Etta Rosales, May Rodriguez, archival footage of Cory and Ninoy, etc
Surely people will watch to the end to hear about the Marcos regime declaring martial law, their various torture methods against dissidents, their rapes of female prisoners, etc
Then Imelda will just look like a ridiculous liar, surely
It brings to mind Truffaut's observation that it's impossible to make a truly antiwar film, because any depiction of war will out of dramatic necessity make war seem compelling

Imelda is a next-level entertaining fabulist and even when she's showing you her Michelangelo and Picasso paintings, which were extremely obviously bought with stolen money, it's hard for her not to suck you in, at least a little bit
You still hear her idealized tales of Ferdinand; you still see her handing out pesos to poor street children
You tell yourself, "I'm smart enough not to be taken in by this," but here we are four years after this film's release, and Bong Bong is president
The choices of what to emphasize from Marcos's crimes are odd
Who gives a shit that he had an ill-advised zebra park
During Marcos's presidency, wages in Manila fell by more than half
The fact that he led the nation to economic ruin and worsened poverty is at most glanced at, not emphasized
I get the logic
I spent the Trump years focusing on the objectively ridiculous and funny aspects of his tenure (the hamburger feast, putting candy on the minion's head) because it was a way to cope
But some crimes are best confronted with a tone other than detached irony

Not a great introduction for the uninitiated to Immelda Marcos, largely because - aside from alluding to a state sanctioned assassination of a political rival - it takes over an hour before you really hear another side of the story than hers
Yes, one can intuit that as the wife of a dictator living a grossly opulent life she probably wasn't a great person
But this documentary lets her have it all her own way for far longer than it challenges her
I suspect the intention was to make the final half hour feel like a withering rebuke of all of the lies she has told, but it feels a bit imbalanced
Like the filmmakers forgot that they were interviewing a monster until right at the end
Still, it's a fascinating look at the level of self delusion someone like her will stoop to

You cannot talk about Ferdinand Marcos’ dictatorship without talking about his wife
American director Lauren Greenfield not only paints a pretty complete picture of Imelda Marcos and her influence but also lays the ground for the future of Philippine politics
It was important that this documentary was an American production because the Marcoses would never have openly bared their stolen wealth to Philippine media
Greenfield and her team had access to one-on-one interviews with the late dictator’s family and their ostentatious households
But with every memory Imelda recalls, and every art piece she shows off, Greenfield counters them with testimonials from Martial Law activists and victims
This results in exposing the delusion the Marcoses live in
The documentary also chose Calauit Island to represent the Marcoses’ effect on the country
The regime initiated many costly projects, but Calauit Island was a fever dream
Indeed, Imelda dreamt of beautifying the country with poached animals from Africa at the cost of the natives of Calauit Island
Today, the island is long forgotten but the animals remain and are neglected
Similarly, the dictatorship had left the country in shambles, with mounds of debt and a fractured political infrastructure
The Kingmaker isn’t just a retelling of the past
The latter half of the film follows Ferdinand Marcos Jr
’s bid for the vice presidency in the 2016 elections
While he narrowly lost, a new dictator stepped in and echoed the crimes of his father
Here, Greenfield concludes the film with a warning of history repeating
Looking back, and considering Marcos Jr
’s recent win in the 2022 presidential elections, The Kingmaker is an excellent explanation for how and why we got here

From the director of Queen of Versailles, one of my all-time favorite docs, comes another movie about a matriarch proud to show off her family’s sickeningly decadent lifestyle
And Imelda Marcos makes the previous documentary subject look Mother Teresa
There’s simply too much story here for the constraints of a 100 minute documentary

While her other doc had the advantage of focusing on a simple story rooted in events most viewers didn’t need primers on, this one has the challenge of conveying recent Filipino history, Imelda’s nine decades of life, her son’s political trajectory and the election of former President Duterte
What’s here is never less than fascinating (it’d be shocking if it weren’t) but it should’ve had at least double the run time to breathe

This a great entry point in the history of the Marcoses but denies any further information to paint the whole story—similar to a politician who says the "right" things but is still partly lackadaisical in action
This is critical because the documentary showcases other important political personalities as respectable, without much criticism for what they've done to the Philippines
It's a story with missing characters and missing acts
Riveting and deeply depressing, especially in the wake of the recent election results
Greenfield smartly allows Imelda to hang herself on numerous occasions, but a smart choice of talking heads helps explain why she retains some popularity, despite her evil

Not only is THE KINGMAKER a fascinating documentary about Imelda Marcos, but it's also about the Marcos family's rise to power during her husband's reign as the president of the Philippines
I can see why director Lauren Greenfield wanted to tackle Imelda Marcos for this doc
If you know her previous two films, you know that she documents wealthy people, and what is the meaning of being wealthy
Not only does the Kingmaker fit in with those prior films, it also shows how awful Marcos' reign was when Ferdinand Marcos declared Martial Law in the Philippines
It seemed like the Marcos family cared more about themselves with all the money and wealth they had instead of helping out the people of the Philippines
It's a sad reality that now Imelda's son BongBong is now the current president of the Philippines after the doc ended
Now I understand why a lot of Filipinos are against the Marcos name since they didn't do a lot of good for their country
Still, this is a great documentary about a divisive figure in Imelda Marcos

"Perception is real, and the truth is not

"One of the first images that come to mind when watching this film is simply of an old woman, clad in Filipino dress, in a gilded room, adorned with paintings by Picasso and Monet, with golden idols strewn across the tables and in a room that harkens back to kings and queens of old, as she tells her story about how bad she had it
It's a lie, of course, as most things that the Marcos family has, have and will say, but it's a lie people believe

Imelda Marcos understands the power the media has, the way she contorts and changes her words to fit the narrative she wants us to believe, but the editing doesn't allow her words to come out unscathed, juxtaposing her picturesque words with words and footage of torture, punishment and other such catastrophes that could make even the most sympathetic follower squirm
But it's not enough

Of course, it's easy to say that putting her in front of the camera is a good or bad idea, but we often forget that words don't exist on their own in film, they come from the interaction between shots, and even the relationship between footage and audio, and placing neutrality and restraint against an obviously inhumane person is immoral

Covering someone like Imelda Marcos, a person who has almost complete control and understanding over her image is tricky to make well, especially as an outsider like Greenfield, but if you want to cover Marcos, and all of their infamy, especially the person who essentially serves, and still does, as right hand man of her family, you have to be unrelenting and unflinching
As the Philippines evolves, technology moves forward, and the way we consume and the way we determine what is just and true gets harder everyday
It is imperative we are aware of this as our history becomes rewritten, crimes of the past become null and dynasties rise back to power
We have to be aware of these things, these ideas that media can be manipulated and used as propaganda, as agents of control because all media exists that way

Triumph of the Will, a 1935 film depicting Hitler and his Third Reich, is notorious for shaping the way we view the Nazi Party, less as an army breaking apart at the seams as they slaughtered one another due to paranoia, and more of an unrelenting force set out to destroy all we know and love
This disconnect from reality and fiction led to our newfound perception of these people, and it is happening to us

By simply giving these people a platform, by giving them full reign on how they are covered, how they are broadcast nationally, we are giving them the power to manipulate, and it is happening all over, as seen within the film
That's why, when we come to critique this family, we have to take them swiftly and dangerously, not leaving shallow cuts, but scathing stab wounds
Ferdinand Marcos is not a hero, he was a fascist
Plain and simple

He embezzled government funds, he tortured, killed and violated his people and he left wounds we are still covering from, and this revisionist history we have now, the way even the lower classes, who were hit hardest, still believe that crimes are to be ignored in favor of worshipping a past that never existed is something to be concerned about
These crimes were never reconciled with, they have no closure and they are still open to this very day

The animals Imelda Marcos released upon Calauit are still hanging there, the stolen jewelry she has is still not returned, and the system that these people manipulated and used is still not fixed, as seen by the blood on our streets and cries in the middle of the night, with politicians who believe that blood of the poor spilled by corrupt cops is valid
The people have every right to be angry, but we should be critical and understand our history, especially after the current context of the son of the late dictator, Ferdinand Marcos Jr
, bearing the name of his father, has won the election, along with Rodrigo Duterte's daughter, who has killed people in the name of his "drug war
" We have a history of revolutions, some won and some lost, and the fight for liberty doesn't stop when someone wins or loses
It is won through continued and watchful progress, through knowledge and the acknowledgement of the past and through wisdom to see through the lies
Anger is in our blood, use it wisely

The Kingmaker is the story of ruthless and narcissistic Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines, and her family’s attempts to work their way back into power after her husband’s overthrow
Imelda was the wife of the corrupt Ferdinand Marcos, who ruled the country between 1965-1986

In interviews she comes across as caring, generous, and eccentric, but the documentary reveals the more sinister aspects of her and her husband's rule; in particular the theft of billions from the country and a period of brutal dictatorship involving torture, rape and murder
During martial law in the Philippines over 3,000 people were killed and 70,000 imprisoned, some for as little as being at a meeting with five or more people
Activists appear in the film with chilling stories of being tortured and sexually assaulted under the Marcos regime
The reign of terror lasted until Ferdinand was overthrown after trying to rig an election in 1986, ushering in democracy in the country over the protests of some of America’s Cold War hawks
It’s never clear how involved Imelda was in the worst acts of her husband’s government, although there are hints in the film that she helped to mastermind the assassination of an opposition leader
It is obvious that she benefitted from the record-breaking corruption of the Marcos regime; as a result her habit of handing out wads of money to the poor takes on a sinister air
If there is one word to sum up Imelda, it is narcissistic

Throughout the documentary her hunger for popularity goes beyond all reason; she sees nothing wrong with importing giraffes and zebras into a country where there are no vets to take care of them, leaving them suffering from skin diseases
At one point, she seemingly sincerely says that Chairman Mao told her that she could end the Cold War

Her accumulation of wealth goes beyond practical levels and seems compulsive; her family looted a literally record-breaking amount of money and helped to impoverish The Philippines for decades, and on a more petty level she was famous for having a collection of over 3,000 shoes
You could say that Imelda is similar to Trump, or alternatively, that Trump resembles any number of self-deluded dictators throughout history, who tend to be self-obsessed in the worst way
Such characters have an enduring appeal despite their ridiculousness, and as many people in the documentary note, the Philippines has been forgiving to strongmen in the past

With Rodrigo Duterte's brutal rule coming to an end and Imelda's son Bongbong Marcos in power in the Philippines as of May 2022, the country may unfortunately be on a path to repeating its previous mistakes

Messy, complicated, compelling doc about a genuinely thorny subject

Sets off as an Imelda Marcos profile with a wicked sense of humour, and slowly morphs into a disturbing exposé of the inbreeding of a political dynasty poised for a comeback (more accurately, the point is that they never really went away)
The film is largely about image maintenance, and it’s fascinating to see Marcos so obviously convinced that this film is just another propaganda vehicle
It’s maybe a little too sprawling too quickly, and the story remains ominously unfinished, but I admired the film’s ambition and clarity
“Perception is real, and the truth is not” says Marcos
The film’s relevance extends far beyond the Philippines
"Perception is real, and the truth is not"
These terrifying words come from the delusional Imelda Marcos, whose influence on politics in the Philippines is scary
The Kingmaker interviews Marcos at length, only for it to become clear that she is a greedy liar seeking to play the victim
Her opulent lifestyle and desire to birth a paradise is slowly realised to come from a scary place

As The Kingmaker is mostly a conventional documentary, aside from its lack of chronology, it feels likely to become a neoliberal piece of mild condemnation without the guts to pick apart Filipino politics
Yet The Kingmaker does find a voice, and manages to find fault in the more liberal governments in the Philippines
Their inability to solve the problems are shown by the film's eventual focus on the resurgence of the Marcos family and their proxy candidate, the evil Rodrigo Duterte
It is a sad and scary time for the Philippines and really this story is still breaking
Who knows if The Kingmaker is telling this slice of history at its beginning or end
There's horrifying moments in The Kingmaker, such as the chilling accounts of torture, the children who openly like martial law, and the fact that Rodrigo Duterte has any power
As a documentary this may not be very inspired, but the subject matter is vital for us all to know
The inbreeding nature of politics has allowed one family to have influence, either overtly or covertly, over an entire country for decades
Perhaps Imelda Marcos does have a plan for paradise, but is the path to it justifiable
2019 Ranked
A real disappointment

Where The Queen of Versailles provided a real examination of its subjects, set against the backdrop of the financial crisis, this film throws its hands up at meaningful probing and morphs into a filmed Wikipedia article

It's pleasant enough to watch, but the people who applauded and harrumphed in solidarity with the final text captions could have just read an article on the 2016 Philippine election to get the same reaction

*followed by a Q&A featuring Director Lauren Greenfield*Imelda Marcos isn’t someone I was familiar with at all prior to this documentary but it didn’t take much to see how she is a prime candidate for a film
Her personality is eye catching and confusing while also being headstrong and assertive
The Q&A that took place following the screening helped improved my view of the film as some of the director’s choices made more scene after hearing how they came to be
One issue I had/have is the level of focus early on on Imelda’s bring of animals to an island and running off its prior inhabitants
While this is an interesting and quirky story, it is later followed up with the film’s first deep dive into the era of Marshall Law in the Philippines brought on by her late husband Ferdinand Marcos

This is far more interesting and far more important to the narrative than this island full of giraffes and I had issues with the time allotment of the two, as well as how much of the earlier portion of the doc feels far too casual given the level of information that is conveyed in the later half
While still is problematic for me, it helped to hear that over the process of filming this movie, much of the later events weren’t even in play yet
So at the time the film felt like it was going to be one thing before new storylines emerged
It doesn’t completely remove my issues about it but it make more sense and for me makes it more understandable a choice

It is a documentary worthy of keeping an eye out for as I think much of it will be a welcomed source of information for most about the political issues in the Philippines and how people like Imelda can be so influential to even if from a distance she looks like a comical character of sorts
To a person who only knows the history of the Marcos dynasty from the Wikipedia article this was appropriately terrifying and illuminating

There are some major issues with the film itself; I can't be sure but it feels like Laura Greenfield went in expecting to just do a bio/exposé on Imelda but then got ensnared in the insanity of 2016 national election

The movie struggles with mission creep; the last 30 minutes depicting the results of that surprising election unfold at breakneck speeds that barely hang together and then at the end require a long series of title cards
It feels tacked-on but I'm not sure that there was any other way to convey the insane turn the story was taking

The explosive story of Imelda Marcos, and her rise from being Miss Manila in Phillipines to becoming the First Lady there

Inspite of years or corruption, political manipulation, murders, and even after being sent to exile out of the country; She still managed to come back, and remains relevant because of her political tact and emotional manipulation of the people of Phillipines
Lauren Greenfield ("The Queen of Versailles," "Generation Wealth") has once again proven why she's my favorite documentary filmmaker, and one of my favorite filmmakers, period

She explores new territory in "The Kingmaker," without straying away from her signature "photographic" and intimate style; the DNA of her style is felt and serves as a backbone to new elements that elevate it to another level in order to successfully cover the story of Imelda Marcos and politics in The Philippines

Everything I admire about her body of work is present on this one: Metaphors of excess and unbalance and its consequences; glamour and its beauty, but also how comical it can be; the obsession with material things and its demons
However, due to the nature of the subject, it goes a step further, diving into political territory and giving us a cautionary tale about power and greed that is harsh, timely, but hopeful
This project might not have been the culmination of 25 years of work like "Generation Wealth," but it's probably the most challenging one Greenfield has had to make
The challenges of this five-year endeavor are seen and felt on the screen, but they pay off
If Greenfield and her team were able to accomplish this, then I cannot wait to see what's next in store
I highly recommend this documentary: A portrait of a woman in and out of power; of a country in and out of justice; of a political system in and out of the past
If you're in LA or New York, make sure you catch it in theaters starting November 8th

While Lauren Greenfield’s previous films (Queen of Versailles, Generation Wealth) have been political, her newest, The Kingmaker, is her first to be overtly about politics
But her pet themes are still on display

The site of Imelda Marcos mobbed by children and adults as she hands out cash or of Ferdinand Marcos’ body, still lying in state and preserved under glass nearly 30 years after his death, are just the newest exhibits in Greenfield’s cinematic museum highlighting grotesque displays of wealth
Read the full review at Battleship Pretension:battleshippretension
A worthy introduction to the madness that is Philippine politics
It's a crash course on the Marcoses and one of the darkest eras in the Philippines

While its attempt at weaving the incumbent leadership with the Marcos dynasty can at times be a stretch, as a Filipino, I can see how this might be the image that non-Filipinos have of the Philippines
As with most films and rooms that she inhabits, Imelda Marcos is magnetic
She's a modern-day Rasputin, who can hypnotize people and place them under her spell
Perhaps it is not the filmmaker's intention that when we do not hear from Imelda for a stretch of time, the movie slows down to a halt
In those long stretches, we yearn for more Imelda on screen
Like the Philippines, we are smitten from the first minute to the last
And suddenly, even with all the horrors that they are responsible for, we realize why the Marcoses keep coming back and back to haunt Filipinos until our dying days
“Perception is real, the truth is not”

One of the ways you can tell how good Lauren Greenfield is at this sort of picture is that she's able to highlight how magnetic and seductive a subject like Imelda Marcos is while laying the groundwork for how tremendously destructive she can be
This could play like trucking the audience, but instead she's just bringing this thing out and cleaning off the surface until a more clear picture emerges

Imelda Marcos is many things: the former first lady of the Philippines, a popular figure in that country, someone who loves fashion, a collector of fine art, and a devoted family person
She imagines herself to be many other things: Chief among them is her self-professed role as the "mother of the Philippines

" The truth, of course, has little to do with such hollow or imagined descriptions, and The Kingmaker, a documentary portrait of Marcos that only becomes more terrifying as it progresses, cuts to the core of what happens when one person's ego becomes more important than the welfare of a country

"The Kingmaker" begins as an unfettered check-in on the life of one of the 20th century's most notorious figures, Imelda Marcos
Like a visit to the zoo, we're granted the opportunity to observe the seemingly self-delusional Marcos in her current habitat as she dreams of a time and place she no longer occupies
Filmmaker Lauren Greenfield allows Imelda the chance to justify, in her own words, her and her late husband's ruthless and corrupt reign as the authoritarian overlords of the Philippines
Greenfield doesn't assist Imelda in her efforts to rewrite history, but she allows Imelda to state her case even as the film mixes in interviews from former friends and enemies (and victims)

There are even moments of humor during the film's early-going, as Imelda's obliviousness to the audience's feeling of disgust toward her wastefully lavish and cartoonish lifestyle, cruel indifference for the rights of her fellow countrymen, and insistence on innocence lands perfectly as a joke at the former Filipino First Lady's expense
However, the film transforms into something far uglier and more frightening as Greenfield transitions from mere case study to political exposé (albeit, one that could be a bit more focused)
Like watching a horror film, "The Kingmaker" turns the joke around on the Filipino people and the audience

Laugh as you might at Imelda and her seemingly fantastical defenses of the Marcos regime and her pipe dream of seeing her son, BongBong, someday elevated to the presidency, the terrifying and telling reality is that Imelda has not yet been relegated to 20th century has-been

At nearly 90, she's a member of the Filipino House of Representatives, the mother of an influential Filipino senator (her daughter) and a very possible future president (her son), and a behind-the-scenes benefactor of the current authoritarian-leaning president, Rodrigo Dutarte
Delusional though she may be, Imelda is still as cunningly manipulative as ever
Hell, she may be once again controlling the strings of power in the Philippines, more than 30 years after she and her husband were forced into exile
It's the kind of film that sends a chill down your back as the credits roll
Very sickening tough watch

Beneath the thick make-up and perfected smile of Imelda Marcos there seems to be something more sinister and unnerving about her appearance

“Perception is real and truth is not,” she says when speaking about accusations of torture and abuse of power, and it's this understanding of how to manipulate her image that has enabled her to remain outside of a prison cell for so long

It’s a warped form of cognitive dissonance that director Lauren Greenfield has captured in her documentary, The Kingmaker, showing the rise, fall and steady rise again of the Marcos clan in the Philippines
Greenfield has spent much of her career documenting the rich and deluded, which made Marcos the perfect subject
She is famous for her lavish lifestyle which included the ownership of thousands of luxury brand shoes and the spending over $2 billion of state money during her time in power

But the longer Greenfield spent with Imelda, the more obvious it became she was an unreliable narrator, locked away in a fantasy bubble refusing to face up to the pain her family has caused the Philippine people for the past half century
Imelda dominates the first half of the film speaking about her journey to government alongside former husband, and now deceased President, Ferdinand Marcos
At the same time she is galvanising support behind her son, Bongbong, while he seeks election as Vice President

Greenfield managed to secure good access to the former First Lady with a one-on-one interview at home, also following her as she travels through the Manila slums (“it never used to be like this” she says with faux incredulity) handing out cash from the huge wad fixed to her side
She makes a good fist of playing the ‘woman of the people’ role, but it is little more than a sham

Imelda Marcos is given free rein to exhibit her own folly and delusion, while interspersed archival footage and other interviews show the true story of the Marcos regime in the Philippines
While generally a troubling and depressing story, The Kingmaker has its lighter moments and dark comedy, a tonal mix that Greenfield manages beautifully
The ending hints at the possibility that Rodrigo Duterte's election as president may have been part of some larger plot to return a scion of the Marcos family to power
While interesting, I'm not sure this theory is fleshed out enough to merit inclusion

Lauren Greenfield has made films about people with immense wealth before, and both those and her books tend to cover that uncomfortable collision of aspirational wealth and real lived experiences, about little corners of the human psyche (or rather bigger ones in some cases) that desire the glossy fashion spread lifestyle
Imelda Marcos largely fits neatly into that, but with a far bigger and more dangerous political footprint that continues to make itself felt

Ostensibly the title is about her relationship with her husband, the massively corrupt dictator of the Philippines for two decades from the mid-60s to the mid-80s (at which point he was ousted by a 'People Power' revolution via the wife of an assassinated opposition leader, Corazon Aquino), whose power she was said to manipulate for her own ends, most famously for the acquisition of art, designer items and of course shoes
But the film moves quickly on from these trappings to her real and lingering effect on Filipino politics, via her family's dynasty and their support for current dictator-wannabe Rodrigo Duterte

Stylistically it frames Marcos with the opulence of her living spaces, repeatedly showing her handing out money to her loyal supporters crowding around her car or in public appearances (often held and distributed by her staff)

She shows off art and photos of her with world leaders (at one point hilariously, but utterly unconcernedly, breaking some of these framed highlights while reaching to show off one, I think with her and Nixon)
She is also apparently blithely unaware of how her namedropping comes across, especially when she's talking about aforementioned world leaders or her art collection

She could be a figure of fun, but gradually the film becomes more and more serious about her impact, as it layers on the Marcos's crimes and the real effects of the policies and division they have sowed within the society, paving the way for her and her family's chilling return to power
The worst kind of villains are the villains who believe that they are doing the right thing
It is clear from this brutally honest documentary that she truly believed she was incapable of doing no wrong

To quote the film "Hustlets" from this earlier this year, "motherhood is a mental illness" and Imelda and the whole Marcos family are the cause of the various illnesses that run plague in my home country
Being a Filipino who lives abroad is a blessing as I am away from the violence and disasters back home, but a curse because I cannot be more than an observer
I can only do my part to try and fight the cynical thoughts in my head saying "we have always been corrupt" "there is nothing we can do", "that is just how things are done"
I've been apathetic to injustice due to my privilege
I am grateful for the life I have and what has been provided for me but it is that privilege that has made me not care
The Kingmaker has awakened a deep anger inside me regarding what has been done to my country
I emplore all Filipinos who have access to it, to see it
Even if you disagree with it
I guarantee all Filipinos can take something from watching it
I can only hope that the Marcos' never return to Malacañang
I'm pleased to report that this is a far superior and less odiously self-indulgent that Greenfield's Generation Wealth

The Kingmaker starts from a position of curiosity and sympathy (there's something of The Fog of War in Jocelyn Pook's Philip Glassy score); Imelda Marcos as ridiculous but tragic, and maybe misunderstood
The second half of the film morphs into Act of Killing territory and the testimony of victims of the Marcos dictatorship cause the mask to slip
Her attempts to propel her David Brent-like son to power likewise move from mildly pathetic to deeply troubling
Ultimately a film that speaks to a variety of worrying political trends across the world, and how perception trumps truth at all turns

Really brilliantly constructed - the film sets up as a cosy, cute, harmless portrait of an eccentric celebrity in her grey years, and allows itself to remain in that framework as the body count grows higher, as Kissinger dances on the screen, as the talking heads, initially brought in to provide sappy reminiscing about Imelda's public life, begin to admit propping up dictators for the US' foreign policy interests or detail their sexual assault at the hands of the Marcos regime, as the gormless Jeb Bush-like son goes from affable mummy's boy to a brutal example of the violence of capital exerting itself, and of course as it ends with the still-unfolding nightmare of Duterte

The usefulness of this for the film is that it provides an aesthetic critique of the influence of capital on society by relating everything back to Marcos, in that we see that all its awful violence, its total control over humanity, its manufacturing of poverty and suffering, don't serve some sort of greater noble cause, but instead simply exist so that an elite can buy shoes and completely bizarre confirmations of their self-image

It's useful sometimes to remember how utterly ugly it all is, and how power has no correlation to either intelligence or beauty, it just exerts itself in service of itself - I'd never immediately disbelieve someone who told me the rich devote their whole lives to worshipping Molloch and doing satanic rituals, because there's no need for these things to be real for the idiotic rich to exploit the world in practicing them, as Marcos' obsessive world-mother fantasy and surreal safari island show
The woozy, nightmarish quality of the film's descent into horror doesn't distract from the reality, and it's a serious documentary that isn't reductive to just pointing at the absurdity of the rich

Instead, it uses these contrasts to make the total dominion of capital in public life and its attendant brutality that protects and asserts the power of the dominant elite all the more vivid, and shows how apparently laughable figures like Duterte can exist as the sinew between capitalism and fascism, artificially creating a need and then fulfilling it with a solution that has no alternative (or, a failed neoliberal alternative), like Marcos literally buying the affection of the poor she helped impoverish

It's that clear critique of capital as a structure and empathy for the oppressed throughout that keeps it from being just liberal aesthetic critique, although mockery of the venal rich still has its place - don't let unfunny US talk show hosts take it away from you completely

Do we feel something when we see Imelda Marcos being pushed around in a wheelchair, or when her memory seems to fail her, or when she betrays some delusion about her place in history
Yes, because we have empathy; unlike some of those currently occupying high office, we're not complete sociopaths

Yet the movie leaves us in little doubt that these most performative signs of weakness - as with any suggestion that Imelda might be considered a victim - may in themselves be a show, a form of spin, and that they are as nothing when one sets them against the lifetime of pain and suffering endured by the Filipino poor

Greenfield induces that wary, guarded empathy one might feel in close proximity to a wounded lion or wolf, creatures that, though laid low, may just rally long enough overnight to make a second lunge for your throat or chest
Even if they can't eat you, their more vigorous offspring still might

The documentary makes some unfortunate choices

Noynoy Aquino quotes Santayana about how those who cannot remember the past are doomed to repeat it, ironic considering how his administration's neoliberal policies contributed to the conditions that helped put another despot as depraved as Marcos into power

The Marcoses are depicted as deluded oafs buoyed by the current of their unearned wealth, creating optics that somewhat distance the family from the atrocities they're responsible for, especially for those who are only learning about Imelda through this film

In one short scene, public school students casually repeat misinformation about Martial Law, mirrored in a sequence where Imelda makes the same claims to the period's secure and prosperous nature, set against archival images and footage of arrests and accounts of torture at the hands of police employed by the Marcoses
It is chilling, heartbreaking, infuriating, and makes it clear that despite Greenfield's documentary covering well-treaded ground, the message bears repeating

I think the most important thing that The Kingmaker did was to directly connect the Marcoses to Duterte - the money, the power, the influence, the strategy, the long con - in a way that is easy for people to follow and understand
Infuriating and frustrating to watch how this same story played out twice in our lifetimes
The main takeaway is proper education
Even I don’t remember being taught about the horrors of Martial Law in elementary and high school - I remember only memorizing that Marcos was the president that stayed the longest in power
Which is useless

If not for university, I probably would be as clueless as these kids in the movie, especially with how active the Marcoses are paying people to revise history to their advantage - which as we saw, our unreliable narrator Imelda Marcos has obviously started to believe and claim as historical facts
Also, how was it possible that after EDSA Revolution and TWO Aquino presidencies that there is still no memorial or museum detailing the atrocities of Martial Law
This is why we always forget
Germany has its Holocaust memorial, and even Cambodia has the same for the Polpot genocides
How do we not have any
Why do we go to theme parks for field trips instead of a Martial Law museum
Sad thing is, it’s too late now
Not going to happen with the current government, after what we’ve seen in The Kingmaker

Lauren Greenfield has always had this strange fascination with showing how wealth corrupts people and how excess magnifies eccentricity
I went to an exhibit of hers sometime last year and found it interesting how so many of the portraits were of Imelda Marcos
Imagine my excitement, then, when I found out that the reason behind that was that Greenfield was making a documentary about Imelda
Finally, the wider world would know about the regime that tore our country into pieces
The Kingmaker is mostly successful at that, but it hardly treads new ground
She is portrayed in the documentary like she is portrayed in other international cultural works that feature her: eccentric, charismatic, having led a charmed life, having possessed 3000 shoes
In the end you have to wonder if it's Greenfield who's "tricking" Imelda into making this doc, or it's Imelda who's playing Greenfield
Strangely enough, the section that made it most interesting for me is what probably made it a weaker documentary
There is a 30 minute digression where we hardly see Imelda, and instead focus on the 2016 Vice Presidential elections
The family sees it as a chance to regain power and redeem their name, but their delusions of grandeur and desperation are only magnified
And while Bong Bong Marcos lost the elections, it is apparent that their power only grows stronger with the allegiance of Rodrigo Duterte
It feels less cohesive as a documentary as a result, but at least we're seeing something new
So is it good
I feel it is
Is it enough
While there was a heartbreaking series of interviews with Martial Law victims, it is only implied that Imelda Marcos has something to do with this
Why was there no coverage of the convictions in international courts
Why was there no definite statement about the guilt of this woman
The Kingmaker is just another piece of cinema that perpetuates Imelda Marcos's legend
What I want to see is an outright condemnation of this woman, because she deserves nothing less
Never forget

Imelda Marcos was the wife of Ferdinand Marcos, dictator of the Philippines from 1965 to 1986, when she and her husband fled into exile
But in the early 1990s her family returned to the Philippines and in the 2010s began it's return to the frontline of politics, seeking office for her son Bongbong
This film, with a tone of mounting horror, relates their appallingly successful efforts to return to power, the facts as frequently jaw-dropping as they are terrifying
For 90 minutes we watch this despicable cartoon villain throw herself a pity party while others suffer the consequences of her vomit-inducing luxury
The ripest metaphor at the films centre is the safari park she and her husband built, evicting hundreds of families from their island home to make way for animals poached from Africa
The film doesn't quite sell this as a metaphor for the political inbreeding, but it remains an incisive example of the cruelty and selfishness these vile humans spread

The initial catalogue of corruption, fraud, ignorance, exploitation and negligence gradually gives way to the insidious background whispers of genuine atrocities committed, before, in the final act, the curtain is fully drawn back and the extent and immediacy of the consequences of their unquenched thirst for power are lain bare and we finally grasp how urgent and real the threat these people pose democracy truly is
It is the rising panic of witnessing the wave of populism and post-truth over the last half a decade condensed down into 90 minutes

Initial disbelief mixed with a touch of amused mocking scorn, before the prickling sense of unease and ultimate bone chilling realisation that this is our reality now and these people, the worst of humanity, utterly devoid of self-reflection, empathy, intelligence or decency, really are running the world
It's a stunningly effective, if incomplete, account of our nightmare modern reality
The Kingmaker: Or The Court's FoolSome people say there shouldn't be any platform anymore that would let Imelda Marcos speak
Anything that seems to come out of her mouth serves no higher purpose than to arouse her narcissism as nothing she says adds any real value to what we already know
Squeezing a reasonable statement from her is futile
This documentary would've worked without her
But the thing is: if given the chance for myself, I would've let it all be and made the documentary all about her relishing in her nonsense
No seriously, let me explain
From the cartoonish first shot of Imelda giving bills to the frenzied poor, The Kingmaker had a sense of a mockumentary in it that aims to highlight Imelda's delusions
For a second, I was suspicious about the prospect of this film hellbent on being pro-Imelda propaganda
But then it went somewhere and I realized: the film is not trolling us, it is trolling the Marcos matriarch herself
And in some moments of brilliant comedy, it seems that even she is trolling herself
It looks like I am watching The Office (2005), even though I never did see an episode of The Office
Or a Taika Waititi political satire akin to What We Do In The Shadows (2014), but tyrants instead of vampires, even though I never did see What We Do In The Shadows
By then you ask, "Is this reviewer full of himself
This is the Marcoses we are talking about for crying out loud
None of this is a laughing matter
"And so I answer, "Comedy here is so intentional, you must have been an idiot or a hardcore Marcos fanatic to miss it
"Greenwood's editing in The Kingmaker is so deliberate in making its subject ridiculous
There are times when scenes should've ended, but then she decides to linger into awkward pauses
Some cuts evoke absurd motifs that elicit restrained laughs
Restrained because they are positioned in instances where the situation programmed you to feel something else
I sure wish the documentary went in this direction completely
Relax, it did go into serious territory
And at this point, the film starts to falter
At least in a self-deprecating mockumentary, you would have focus
Greenwood's fault is that she tried to inject a little bit of everything in the narrative of The Kingmaker hence making the documentary boggled and frustratingly on the fence
It is obviously against tyranny, of course
But then again the documentary could've been appropriated and misread as a loving portrait of the old hag by some people
Which did happen for some appalling reason
By then you ask, "Is a mockumentary more susceptible to misinterpretation
" And so I stubbornly answer, "Shut up
I know
At least we had the unapologetic LOLs
"However, as an informative piece that serves as an entry-level lesson to our history, The Kingmaker is highly successful
It even shed light on lesser known controversies that Imelda managed to get her hands on - the Calauit island conversion to an African safari and displacement of its indigenuos people
But you could still accuse the documentary for being pandering to liberals
It portrays the Aquinos as eventual heroes to history, as if the Cory Aquino administration saw significant improvement in the country's atmosphere
Which it didn't, as things arguably went worse

The documentary has an oversimplified black-and-white approach to the subject it tackles that could be a disservice to the complexities of our history, a possible by-product of Greenfield being an outsider
It works for students and foreigners, the latter of which is the real audience of the film
But to people who already made up their minds, there's only so much that this film could do
In a perfect world, The Kingmaker would educate more people on the truth of our history
And it would push loyalists to be more critical of their politics
Hell, in a perfect world, there would've been no need for The Kingmaker
But this isn''t a perfect world
In all seriousness, films like these are noble efforts and should be made more often
Only people should be more critical of what they watch

In lesser seriousness, let me end by cherishing this gem of a scene from the documentary: There's a scene where Imelda recounts how she hid diamonds in diapers to be taken with her as they try to leave Malacañang due to the People Power Revolution
"Diamonds in diapers,'' jokes Imelda
Then an awkward pause as she hopes for some laughs in the audience
No one laughed
Then I laughed because no one laughed
It's brilliant comedy
