The Kingmaker may have illustrated some agitating parallels between the Marcos regime and the Duterte administration, but much of the film's fascinating quality comes from its deconstruction of Imelda Marcos' delusional psyche

Lauren Greenfield's latest documentary about the Philippines' ex-first lady starts off as a darkly comic portrait of a delusional woman, but later turns into a disgusting tale of a loathsome monster's ambitions & lies
In  , we get a more personal look into the life of former first lady Imelda Marcos, their family's rose to power with her husband, the late Ferdinand Marcos being seated as the country's president
The documentary starts off a bit humorous, with Imelda introducing herself and her life before
The things she tells the camera are quite funny because it makes her look delusional- her actions are mostly eye-rolling (we spend a lot of time watching her give children with banknotes)
It's full of spectacle, with archival footage of her hanging out with foreign leaders like Ronald Reagan, Fidel Castro, Saddam Hussein, and Mao Zedong

But as soon as the interviews with Martial Law survivors enters the picture, you realize that she's an unreliable narrator- the story she's been telling us was leaning towards a certain narrative aiming to cleanse our view towards her, the Marcos family, and Martial Law in general

Imelda is obviously using melodrama to get the poor's sympathy- a strategic story to support their return to power as she & her children, Bongbong & Imee, try to climb the ladder back to the government
What's worse is that they are also trying to revise our country's history, by changing what has transcribed in the past and teaching these fake information to the youth
At one point, some kids were asked what they know about Martial Law
Their answers stupefied me, with all of them saying that it was a 'golden' era for the Philippines
George Santayana was right: those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it
: Definitely a must watch for everyone, with its sharp and biting depiction of Marcos' regime and its connection with today's fascist regime of Duterte
I'm still angry so this might not be as objective
It's uncomfortable and infuriating, knowing that this family who has blantantly abused this country (and still do
) is still not held responsible for their numerous crimes to the state

I find it an interesting direction choice to use Imelda as an unreliable narrator and then juxtaposing that with archival footage and firsthand testimonies of people affected by the 1972 Martial Law, which diametrically opposes what the Marcos family claims

The access Greenfield and her team had with the family is also worth noting because it's quite obvious that they're all putting a show—all part of their scheme to revise history and put themselves back into power
But we know better than that

Greenfield used that access to present something beyond the Marcoses' "show"—families and villagers displaced from their homes because the Marcoses want their very own island zoo, thousands of victims of human rights abuses, even the people working for them that are treated like pawns instead of human beings
But it's a pity they still tried to play it safe
If you're going to give people like the mythmaker a platform, you need to be clear and firm in your stance instead of staying neutral
It's very important to process the film after watching it
People who saw this film should note that all of this isn't about the Marcos-Aquino family feud or a fight between political parties
It's about how this government continually oppresses its people for the sake of vanity and greed

I saw The Kingmaker in UP Film Institute during the 34th EDSA Anniversary, so the milieu made it feel like the movie is preaching to the choir at this point, so I was kind of disappointed that there was little nuance with how it talks about the connections between our current issues and the Marcoses
What's funny, I think, is that in its attempt to show the Marcoses' humanity—or lack thereof—it did not let enough voice from the masses to speak

That's why my favorite parts were when it touched on the Calauit Safari, because it puts the two classes at odds with each other (and how order both in nature and in humans was threatened because of it)
Still, I think it's an important film especially for people who are learning about the family's atrocities for the first time
It would not win the conversion of the diehards or the undecided, but it does solidify one fact and one battlecry: #NeverAgain to a Marcos in power

When people think of Imelda Marcos, usually the first thing that comes to mind is her 3,000 pairs of luxury shoes, her luxury fashion and lavish lifestyle
She was also the first lady of Manila, married to the president Ferdinand
They were in power from 1965 until their removal in 1986
They're widely believed to have illegally amassed a wealth of billions of U
dollars, all of which has never been recovered, holding the Guinness World Record for greatest government robbery
She has since been charged with her dealings and corruption, as well as disqualified from holding any public office
But was later cleared of all previous charges on appeal, and still continues to live in Manila
In this documentary, she's very much still living the lavish lifestyle and gladly shows everyone her priceless collection of luxuries, including paintings and sculptures
It paints a disquieting portrait of the divisive controversial public figure, thanks to Lauren Greenfield's direction, writing and exploration

The interesting thing about Lauren Greenfield's "The Kingmaker" is how the tone of the film shifts midway
The first half of the doc shines on the past, presenting us with Imelda's many eccentricities and extravagant lifestyle that were so funny to learn about
But it then shifts into serious politics of the present where we get to learn that Imelda is still wielding power by helping to elect his son into the Vice-Presidency
It's Greenfield's way of forboding how the country is doomed to repeat history

Love her or hate her, Imelda Marcos is definitely a woman who made history

In short time I'm going to work my way backwards through documentarian Lauren Greenfield's filmography, starting with her most recent film, The Kingmaker, profiling Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of The Philippines
Notable for far more than just her epic shoe collection, Marcos held the reigns of power behind-the-scenes during her family's time in office, and now has hopes to return to the presidential mansion
Greenfield's style in this film is to allow Marcos to tell her own history and her own story at first
We follow her in-person as she is interviewed, talking about her family, upbringing, and rise to power in the mid-1960s

For over two decades, her husband Ferdinand ruled with her at his side, a political power broker and key agent in diplomacy, using her striking looks and infectious charm to be as close to other world leaders -- often conservative, often dictatorial -- as her husband ever was

Famously catching Ferdinand cheating on her with tape recorder under the bed, which she used as blackmail to get what she wanted later, she grew in prestige and influence into the 80s as the family lived like extravagant royalty amidst a nation suffering in abject poverty
It was the 1986 People Power revolution (and election of Corazon Aquino) which forced them from office and exiled the family from ever ruling The Philippines again

Of course, the Marcos regime ruled with an iron fist in a military dictatorship, and gradually through The Kingmaker the stories of others -- those affected by the imposition of martial law, the families evicted from their homes to the Marcos family could build and renovate at will, the torture victims and political prisoners of innumerable amounts -- come to the fore, and the real truth is revealed about Imelda
That is, Greenfield allows her to be an unreliable narrator, and brings in members of the Aquino family and other opponents to counter her fabrications and exaggerations, like a form of fact checking

Along with her son Bongbong who Imelda wishes to see back in the presidential palace again -- and who probably likes Parasite exactly twice as much as you do -- the two craft a fantastical tale of their birthright to rule, while everyone else fights against their corruption and misdeeds as the loving Marcos clan cozies up to current sociopathic president Duterte
Now in her late 80s, Imelda appears unrepentant and even in denial of any of her family's actions
And why would she admit them
She still maintains fabulous wealth that was shipped offshore and retained after exile, still flaunting it in the face of today's Filipino people and using it to further Bongbong's campaign

In a bizarre state of denial about the years of horror her family brought to The Philippines, Imelda plays the victim and twists the facts to beg for sympathy; unfortunately it has worked in some ways, stealing billions from the country while many Filipinos suffered
Greenfield has explored themes of wealth, privilege, and bewildering ignorance of power and influence before, and The Kingmaker does that effectively
The doc plays with a linear timeline a little, and the shifting stories can make it difficult to follow if you don't already have knowledge of the era

I imagine anyone not from the Philippines and especially anyone under 30 might need more background information about this history to fully grasp the evil of the Marcos regime and impact for decades more, as well as how it's profoundly affected the current Duterte era
This film though is an excellent start

Instead we get the other view of things through interviews, which might get at the truth, but don't let us see the delusional/masterful reinterpretation of the past that Imelda employs, which is the real star of the show
In fact, the central question here might be which side of the fine line she is on: is she consciously evil, or does she truly believe the things she is saying

Very interesting and entertaining documentary on Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines who lived in a lavish lifestyle by plundering her nations wealthy, The Kingmaker is an in depth feature that chronicles her legacy
I found the film to be very good and shows that Marcos was quite deceptive and dishonest
It's quite an interesting film to watch and the way things are presented on-screen makes the viewer form his or hers own opinion on Marcos
The film is quite fascinating in what it does, yet I think more things could have been added to the film too
It's quite in depth, but the film could have been a bit longer too
Regardless the documentary covers enough ground to be a very thorough feature on its subject, and it is a very entertaining movie
The Kingmaker is entertaining from start to finish and the film features very good archival footage as well as interviews with Imelda Marcos and those who know her
We get both sides of the story and it is a well constructed genre film

"They found no skeletons
Only beautiful shoes" is just one of the many striking and unbelievable lines that came from former Philippine First Lady Imelda Marcos in Laura Greenfield's documentary "The Kingmaker"
The line exhibits the nonagenarian's lavish perspective despite living in a third world country that suffered from the regime of her late husband and dictator Ferdinand Marcos
Greenfield's documentary shows how "imeldific (ostentatiously extravagant)" the mindset of Imelda despite the numerous human rights violations and embezzlement that happened during the Marcos regime

After all of her controversial past, it is beyond belief how Imelda is firm to declare that the Philippines was in its glory during Martial LawGreenfield portrays Imelda as someone who has a savior complex
Imelda believes that being the first lady means being a mother to everyone so she wants nothing but the best for Filipinos
She visits the streets while aboard her car and gives out money to children
She goes to the hospital and distributes huge bucks like its just coins to her
But being a mother is beyond giving money for Imelda
She wants to convert the country into a paradise that will be looked up by other countries
"The Kingmaker" gives light to the usually undiscussed Calauit Safari Park in Palawan
Imelda was in awe of Africa's beautiful safaris so she bought giraffes, zebras, monkeys, and more African animals and placed them on a small island
The film shows Imelda's inhumane mind when some residents of Calauit island detailed how the military evicted them in favor of the animals that are not even natives in the Southeast Asian Country
It later revealed that the animals there are not properly taken care of because of the absence of a veterinarian who specializes in safari animals

It's an antithesis to Imelda's own perception of being a mother to everything in the Philippines, showing that she's only obsessed with the aesthetic surfaceImelda has also risen to a new societal power when she was shown leading infrastructure projects and buying expensive New York buildings
At some point, it was also suggested that Imelda was the one running the country as her husband is falling ill
"The Kingmaker" shows Imelda as not just a first lady or the "mother" of Filipinos
She is also a puppeteer who can control everyone with the strings made out of Php 1,000 bills
Greenfield was able to show Imelda as an out-of-touch personality who still believes that her family has the solution to everything
However, one has got to ask if Greenfield wants to convince pro-Marcos and moderates to pick the other side
If she has that intention, unfortunately, The Kingmaker" will just serve to them as a "hate piece" to the Marcos supporters and those who are in between
In fact, they may have encountered the 2003 documentary about Imelda but they are still firm on what they believe is right
Moreover, getting Marcos' opponents such as Vice President Leni Robredo and former President Noynoy Aquino (son of slain senator and fierce Marcos critic Benigno Sr
) as the opposing voices to Imelda will more likely fail to convince a lot of people
Hence, the discourse between the Pro- and Anti-Marcos will be just filled with tiring justifications of the authorities' actions
"Perception is real and the truth is not," Imelda said in the documentary
So, the question now is "Which perception is Greenfield trying to appeal
Because if she's appealing to Marcos supporters, the documentary may lack in showing new information on Imelda's ridiculousness
Maybe except for the Calauit safari

The director could have focused her story on that island and meticulously unravel the fate of the residents and the animals there caused by Imelda's shallow vision of a perfect and paradise-like society
Maybe its only flaw is letting Imelda open her mouth
The greatest performance of Imelda Marcos
Deserves an award for being the most conniving, manipulative, and self-centered human
or is she even considered one
In her old age she's still convinced that she gave birth to the greatest era of the Philippines
Bong bong looks like a pet more than a son
You can see how he always seeks for his mother's approval
Imee just looks like the cheap dolls you get at divi — purely plastic
She even got her mother's big hair
Director Lauren Greenfield's documentary not only shows the two sides of politics in the Philippines, but also explains how perception is not that easy to deceive
From watching this film, I kept asking questions like "How do the people not see it
" or "How did she get away with it
Honestly, Annalise Keating should take a lecture from her

I guess that's where her fallacious line "Perception is real, truth is not" comes in
We often attach ourselves to our beliefs and create layers of lies in order to protect them

However, from what was shown I think it was enough to make you understand and even empathize on behalf of the victims
I hope that more people get a chance to watch and educate themselves of how power should not be in the hands of heartless people

I feel super conflicted about this one
It's fascinating and I love Lauren Greenfield
I just feel like
more than her other docs, this story just really got away from her in a way that she wasn't qualified to handle
This is
well, it's objectively empathetic toward Imelda Marcos in that it just shows her for who she is
And unsurprisingly, she's an ambitious, power-hungry person with delusions she's doing the right thing
This documentary is not trying to make you like her, but just understand her
And what I understand about her is not
I really went into this thinking I was maybe going to end up liking her or at least having some sympathy for her, like she was just misunderstood
My takeaway was absolutely the opposite
She's worse than I thought she was
But as the political situation in the Philippines changed, I think Greenfield wasn't really equipped to keep up
It became more of a news story rather than a people story
And that's not her fault
As much as I think she's good at setting out to make one documentary and then ends up making another, in this case, it didn't quite work
I just don't know if she quite had the background to put all of this in the proper context
It's definitely worth watching, though, and the parts of it that work do work really well
And the parts that don't work are still pretty good

Before watching this documentary, I was afraid that it will paint the Marcoses and the late dictator’s term in a good light; that it might be another attempt of the Marcoses’ on historical revisionism
During elementary school, the Marcos regime is dubbed as “The Golden Age of the Philippines”
The usual narratives are: the Philippines was one of the richest countries in Asia; when Marcos declared martial law, there was peace and order; and that he ended poverty
A lot of students are growing up thinking that he was the best president the Philippines ever had
Even I, at one point, believed that
Fast forward to high school, the Marcos dictatorship is once again discussed along with martial law
There I learned that media companies are shut down to censor information, and that he imprisoned his political opponents
However, accounts of torture and murder are not discussed
As I grow older, I encounter more documentaries and articles proving that during his term was not “The Golden Age of the Philippines” (though it might be for his cronies)
Now that information is more accessible with the help of the internet, more information regarding the crimes of the Marcoses are revealed
I remember watching a video on Facebook wherein young people who grew up believing that Marcos is the best president of the Philippines are sat down with a victim of martial law
After the young ones tell why they thought Marcos was good president, the victims then narrate how they were tortured by Marcos’ men
However, the internet has also given a platform to Marcos apologists to propagate the narrative that the Marcos regime was best because of his infrastructure projects
This documentary has let Imelda tell her story without letting her control the narrative
It changed my perception on her position as a first lady
She was more than a lavish woman who indulges in shoes
She was more than an accessory to her husband
Her image as the muse of Manila has helped Marcos ascend into power, and helped him in connecting with other world leaders
Until now, she’s one of the reasons why her children (even after all they have done to this country) has been elected into government positions
Hoping that more people, especially Filipinos, are given the chance to watch this

I never get to go to these festivals, but I try to look at the programming guide and make a schedule as if I was going
I always tried to find room for this film in my make believe schedule

There is a lot of interesting information that is thrown up there to read instead of using time to show it on film

Despite the, in my opinion, lack of focus the film seems to present, it is compelling to hear the thoughts of Imelda
She remains one of the most infamous people of the late 20th century
But I'm not sure that this film ever allows the viewer to fully know her

It’s a cliffsnotes version of the last near decade in the Philippines, and I do think this is the type of cultural artifact that Filipino documentarians cannot really package and broadcast - at the very least for now
The docu’s biggest strength is the way it captures Imelda’s twisted way of thinking
It’s very natural for her to downplay a lot of history, and to drive the narrative convincingly
It’s the same power you see in archival footage of “the Conjugal Dictatorship”, and the same power that is insinuated as puppetry- or at least sponsorship- for the currently sitting Duterte
The nugget quote “Perception is real and the truth is not” is the ironic essence of our time, delivered by the patron saint of Filipino boomers herself
It’s a reminder that what seems new and surprising in the valley of fake news, is just what is and what has always been to a certain breed of alligator

It should be noted that the docu scopes out a lot of nuance, atrocities and products of her Edifice complex in favor of an introductory contrast between the Marcos era and their rise back to power today
Yes, it includes heart wrenching testimonies of essential Martial Law era dissenters, and their harrowing experiences are just the tip of the bloody iceberg

But understandably, you can’t package all nuance into a digestible document, and the target audience is composed of non-Filipinos - but letting them know about the basic stuff is still pretty important

But I think the most important thing they gloss over is the corruption and/or callousness of what came after (it is mentioned, but it could’ve used a few more minutes) and why a nostalgic rose colored filter has colored many of those who lived through the toppling of the Marcoses
There’s a lot in the docu that many critics of the Marcoses already put forward, and a lot that his staunch loyalists deny (or recontextualize), and it’s unlikely to change local perceptions
For those who live in the thick of the topic at hand, a different approach to the documentation of this era seems more fitting
In two more years, the Philippines will either experience another political shift, or lead up to this slow burn of a Marcos return
It’s hard to predict what the Imeldific Kingmaker’s strategy is going to be about, but it likely will be the opposite of beautiful

"Perception is real, the truth is not
"It's a shocking admission, even by Imelda Marcos' standards
But what passes as lazy dialogue from a feature film becomes a damning confession in a documentary
Lauren Greenfield continues her treatise on the corrupting influence of wealth and power
But while Greenfield is retreading familiar territory in The Kingmaker, the sheer size and scope of this semi-biopic dwarfs any of her previous work
Imelda Marcos is a familiar subject for the Filipino people, but Greenfield recontextualizes the delusional former first Lady from within a nation run by President Duterte
The Marcos family is still as narcissistic as ever, and to no one's surprise, is still trying to weasel their way back into power
It's a story the Filipino people should already know by heart, but considering our goldfish memory, it's a story worth retelling until the end of time
As a documentary, The Kingmaker says nothing new
But it does say something important
As a Filipino, however -- tangina mo Marcos balik mo pera namin
an important view
The documentary tries to present two sides of a coin, but ultimately reveals itself to be slanted in the right direction for humane reasons
It is political, gripping, and deeply personal to the Filipino's struggle for justice
The film becomes even more relevant with a narrative on Duterte and how everything potentially ties to the Marcoses' bid for power again
While I would have preferred there was less of Imelda being given the avenue to try and twist history, I know only the ignorant can be fooled by her delusions
Contrary to Imelda's belief, the truth exists and manifests itself to discerning people so that hopefully, we can truly say #NeverAgain
Here is my position: we should never put Imelda Marcos in front of a camera

We should never give her access to any platform whatsoever, because it's just another opportunity for her to spout her lies, all shrouded under the guise of her being this doddering old woman with strange philosophies about beauty and mothering

The film does actively undercut the things that she's saying, but it's an extra step
We do not need to talk to the Marcoses to explore their evil
We do not gain insight by spending time in their palatial homes, with their art and their clothes and all the aspirational bullshit that makes them weird antiheroes in this broken oligarchic society
The best parts of this film are the parts where it talks to victims, where it talks to the poor
The film tries to be clever with its juxtapositions, but the end effect is that it still gives voice to the lies, still allows a truly evil person to revise history
It opens up the possibility of accusations of bias, and letting them play the victim yet again when all they've ever done is victimize the Filipino

It also does a good job in exposing how they perpetrated mediocrity and impunity through her children who are now trying to reclaim the political clout that they lost years ago
There is an undercurrent of rage in the entire documentary, as we slowly see this rotten family rebuild their reputation through deceit and political connections
It ends on a terrifying note: she and her family insist that we forget the past and move on to pave the way for their return
Yet on the other hand, it also needs to be said that this documentary also gave another opportunity for the Marcoses to repeat their lies

The Kingmaker is a documentary about the life and times of one Imelda Marcos, famous First Lady of the Philippines for 21 years
I was generally unaware of her history and her influence going into this, though I'm pretty sure I had an inkling about the shoe thing
The Kingmaker begins innocently enough, starting with Imelda herself
She goes through her history, her upbringing, her marriage, and her pride in the political power she had
She proclaims herself to be "The mother of the nation," a symbol of hope to the masses
People love her, she says, and we're given no reason to think otherwise

Regular documentary viewers may know where this is going; we're being lulled into a false sense of security, before the filmmakers blindside us with a right hook and say, "No, actually, this is how all that really went down
"And how
It becomes clear as The Kingmaker goes on that what we're seeing is a portrait of a raging narcissist, an inconsiderate dictator, and, in all likelihood, a mass-murderer

The film is directed by Lauren Greenfield, and while I've not seen any of her previous documentaries, I can tell looking at their descriptions - The Queen of Versailles in 2012, and Generation Wealth in 2018 - that The Kingmaker falls right into her wheelhouse of examining and deconstructing the insanity of the rich and powerful
Right from the start, Imelda Marcos cuts a fascinating, and infuriating, figure
The first thing we see her do in the film is ride around in her luxury limousine, passing by scenes of abject poverty and complaining, "This used to be my little paradise
In my time, there were no beggars
" Somehow, I don't believe her
Later, we see her handing out giant wads of money to random passersby

This is something we see her do a bit, and we come to understand it's a regular occurrence; she will frequently walk around, or ride around in busses, handing out money to the impoverished masses, who obviously respond with gratitude
That's how she wins their hearts and minds, see
The film plays a tricky game with Imelda Marcos

Right from the start, we're encouraged to not take her at face value; the film highlights the inherently ridiculous nature of her appeals to mass popularity, and her assurance that she's just as powerful and beloved as she was in her prime, when none of that is clearly true
Basically, she begins the film as a clown, a totally ridiculous figure ripe for mockery
Not knowing the extent of her vileness, I assumed that this was a documentary about how a country was damaged through incompetence
Imelda Marcos begins The Kingmaker as a joke, and ends it as a monster

As the net of the documentary's eye widens, and more and more talking heads emerge to tell their stories of what it was actually like under Marcos dictatorship, the film repeatedly returns to Imelda's silent, resilient gaze, and we're forced to ask: "Surely, there's no way you didn't know about this, right
After all, you were just bragging about how you were the secret power behind your husband
Surely, you knew
"In many ways, The Kingmaker is the perfect documentary for our time

because Imelda Marcos IS a clown; she's a vain, pompous, egotistical fool who at one point insists to the camera that she could've solved all the world's problems, because all the world leaders just found her so charming
But behind all that, there's this twisted image of a frilly despot, lounging away as her country starves, and her people are tortured
By her

The Kingmaker I think does an excellent job at painting Imelda Marcos into a corner from which she can't escape, using cutaway evidence and cross-testimony, all while keeping her unaware that this "puff-documentary" is actually a hit piece

I appreciate that there's never really a moment that The Kingmaker allows her to seem sincere; even when the extent to her monstrosity isn't quite apparent, she comes across as a complete egomaniac, with way too much while her country has way too little
But then things get serious, fast

There are hints as to something darker lurking under the surface early on; how she talks about the period of martial law being a golden age, or how she keeps the body of her husband perfectly preserved behind glass, which is just a horrific image
But then we hear about how she imported all these exotic animals to an island, only to abandon the project after the animals proved to be more trouble than they were worth
Those animals are still there, as cross-breeding catastrophes
We hear about the Tunnel of Love, which was built by Imelda's husband for her, and then became the name of a particularly grisly method of torture
And we follow a series of money trails, the end result of which is that the Marcos family seems to have been robbing their country blind

Even more worryingly, the film will frequently cut to the present, where we see Imelda masterminding her son's campaign to be Vice President of the Philippines (Vice President there is different than in America; it's a separate election than that of the President, and the VP generally has more responsibility than they do here), with the money she seems to have stolen directly from the people
It's here that the film begins to lose me a little; by playing with nonlinear chronology, it sometimes becomes hard to track the exact order of events as they happened
And every once in a while, I did find myself wondering, "I wonder what was happening in the rest of the world at around this time
" But the film does succeed at painting a portrait of wealthy insanity, damningly well
The image of Imelda Marcos, now elderly, on the cusp of re-achieving political dominance and still in complete denial about her family's evil legacy, is appropriately chilling
“There are so many things in the past that we should forget
In fact, it’s no longer there
After watching Queen of Versailles, I wanted some more documentaries in my life and went on to look at more of director Lauren Greenfield's work
The Kingmaker popped up and had actually been recommended to me before so I decided to watch
I had a VERY surface level understanding of the political world this documentary showcased
I think this is an example of really great, holistic documentary making
I came out of this with a much greater understanding of the topic without it being too bogged down in talking head interviews
The emotions kept hitting and there was just a really powerful storytelling arc put into place here
One of the best documentaries I've seen in a long time
The Kingmaker is an eye-opener for what happened in the past and what could happen in the future
"Perception is real, and the truth is not
"All I knew about Imelda Marcos was that she was basically the Filipina version of Jackie Kennedy, with her terno sleeves and thousands of pairs of shoes
When the documentary starts, she talks about her role as a First Lady, her husband's infidelities, and her commitment to her country, not as a political official, but as a mother figure
As the film continues, it's clear that Marcos's "mothering" of the nation was nothing more than widespread mismanagement of government funds, corruption, and human rights abuses

I think that the documentary could have introduced this "side" of her sooner, because the first half an hour leads us to believe that she was a formidable force in Philippine politics who was relegated to the sidelines because of her sex
Maybe that's the editing, but it probably has something to do with Marcos's masterful manipulation skills
She knows what to say and how to spin situations, so the documentary is much more powerful when juxtaposing her propaganda with the testimony of real-life witnesses to her crimes
Crimes which, unfortunately, are not explored with much depth
I wish more time had been spent on martial law and her money laundering
However, the half an hour spent on the Marcos family's attempts to re-infiltrate Philippine politics is incredible
They've worked with the current president to arrest their opposition, jail the VICE PRESIDENT, and rig the Supreme Court, all to make Marcos Jr
the president
Imelda Marcos mentions that the country is full of "forgiving" people who love her because she was a "good mother" to them
I hope that, despite all their forgiving, the people don't forget
"Now is the important thing, and the past is the past
There are so many things in the past that we should forget
In fact, it's no longer there
"also, shoutout to Jocelyn Pook for an incredible score

Imelda is a perfect focus on a documentary like this not just because she is arguably one of the most powerful first ladies in all of the world's modern history, but because she is the perfect snapshot of obscene wealth
Imelda has Monet and Picasso paintings and an obscene amount of shoes and clothes
This all happening in a country that is shown to be going through a significant struggle with many of its citizens facing poverty
What puts this film over the top is that it's well-made

The title, The Kingmaker, refers to Imelda, not just with her husband and how she carried so much power especially socially, but we see her trying to build up her son to become that 'king' of the family in the present day
We also see the Marcos Family trying to make the 'king' of Duterte in order to get Bongbong in power quicker
The aspects of a photography shoot just went on to further highlight Imelda's ridiculous wealth
Perhaps most importantly, though, there is the discussion with opponents of the Marcos power that is able to contradict anything that Imelda may be lying about
This is not a film that glorifies Imelda by any means

It doesn't necessarily deal her a vicious takedown, but rather it gives the audience all the tools we need to make the obvious conclusion that Imelda, despite her sob stories and giving out pity-pay to begging children, is neither a good person, nor worthy of our sympathy
There are tons of incredible and sympathetic characters in this film, though
May Rodriguez's story is truly inspiring
Andy Bautista moving to Oklahoma after investigating Imelda out of fear of Duterte and Marcos is harrowing
The residents of the island that the Marcoses used for their private zoo share their story and it's beyond tragic
The zoo animals are the key metaphor for me
It's the tale of the Marcos Family starting something extremely extravagant, funding it well, then dropping it
Now, the animals just linger there, affected by inbreeding and disease
The ignoring of the animals mirrors the ignoring of the people in the Marcos regime and the refusal to own up and help in any real, tangible, way
Money to beggars on the street will not make up for the years of martial law and tactics used to whitewash history in the favor of Marcos

Con un acceso envidiable a Imelda Marcos, el documental captura la delirante percepción maternal y protectora que ella tiene sobre sí misma, mientras entreteje los crímenes de la dictadura de la que fue cómplice
Un inquietante relato sobre el poder y la memoria, donde la angustia no se construye tanto sobre lo que ya fue, sino por lo que se vislumbra en el futuro político de Filipinas y del mundo

Inquietante reconstrucción poliédrica del control político que ha ejercido la familia Marcos en Filipinas, comandados por la matriarca Imelda, bajo la supresión, auspicio y financiación de Estados Unidos, así como la supresión de memoria al pueblo

Dominado por entrevistas a cuadro en un montaje que contrasta los testimonios de victimas y victimarios (quienes han encarnado la dictadura), además de material de archivo televisivo y fílmico del mandado de Marcos, Lauren Greenfield presenta dramáticamente la cuasi monárquica estructura "democrática" en este país del sudeste asiático,el cual por cierto, deja de manera apenas visible la participación estadounidense en este conflicto

Uno de lo valores principales del trabajo es que estampa la ola de la derecha regresando al poder, además de los mecanismos y discursos que utilizan para alcanzar su objetivo, lo que (podría) resulta bastante familiar para espectadores del continente americano

Knowing nothing about history of the Philippines, the Marcos Family or Ferdinand Marcos' time ruling the country, at first this seemed like a documentary about the melancholy Imelda Marcos feels for long lost power and youth
Then you start learning about everything Imelda and her husband did during his presidency (dictatorship, I learned) and how the family is not nearly over with politics

"The Kingmaker" is subtle with how it depicts the cunning and devious ways of Imelda Marcos
Actually, it's up to you as the viewer to decide who to side with - Imelda's words or the stories of those who have been oppressed by her family's decisions in the past
Regardless, "The Kingmaker" is a well-balanced documentary that is entertaining as it is cunningly disturbing
It's the 2016 elections and Imelda Marcos is on a mission to make her son Bongbong Marcos the next vice president of the Philippines

Along the way, we get to know the life and the psyche of the woman before she married Ferdinand Marcos, their power during his presidency, and the eventual downfall of their family in 1986 People Power revolution, and their plot to wipe off her family's sinister reputation especially with the younger generation
From its first few minutes, we see Imelda Marcos calm, cool, and collected
Her charm undeniable and even we, as Filipinos, started believing her words

But Lauren Greenfield does amazing work as she subtlety unveils the perceptive reality that Imelda tries to convey against the backdrop of real people who experienced great tragedy through the actions of her and Ferdinand Marcos
The film's tagline uses Imelda's own words that "Perception is real, and the truth is not
" is the very real horror in this film
If ever she believes her own lies or lies to the heart to get away with guilt, the truth is that almost everything she started failed to prosper in the long run
It's a reflection of both past wrongs that her family did and the present wrongs that Filipinos are experiencing with its modern politicians
Surprisingly, Lauren Greenfield doesn't force much to assassinate the character of Imelda Marcos as Imelda herself unravels herself
The documentary doesn't really side with any party equally portraying the biases of the other camp
Overall, "The Kingmaker" is a film that every Filipino should watch
It's a warning sign that we really need to remember the sins of the past and that our forgiving nature as a populace is our own undoing in the long run

‘The Kingmaker’ se enfoca en la Primera Dama de Filipinas, Imelda Marcos (a la cual ubicaba siempre de ese excelente disco conceptual de David Byrne y Fatboy Slim)

Aquí, la directora Lauren Greenfield nos adentra no sólo a la historia política de su familia (la cual continua hasta la actualidad entre escándalos de corrupción con el actual presidente y la campaña de vicepresidencia de su hijo, Ferdinand), sino con la opulencia de su estilo de vida
Greenfield siempre ha tenido una fascinación por la decadencia de la clase alta y con Marcos ha encontrado un sujeto perfecto
‘The Kingmaker’ me parece su mejor trabajo, como una crónica plagada de corrupción y despotismo

Muy recomendable

Throughout the film there were various commentaries from people and the fact that they weren't positioned in the same background with the exact same static angle was very interesting- each person that gave a commentary gave it in the comfort of either their own home or office with a full frontal view, giving off a feeling of rawness and vulnerability as they spoke, luring the audience to full believe in what they say

In terms of audio, there was one mellow melancholy tune that would play whenever a devastating/unfortunate event was brought up, which would of course elevate the feeling of loss and damage- these two feelings are important because that's the main goal of the documentary: for the people to feel the loss and damage that has happened to the Philippines and the people because of the abuse of power by the Marcos family
Although the film revolved around Imelda, I deeply appreciated how it did not feel biased at all
The people behind the film didn't just interview and capture people in awe of Imelda, but also brought in people who found the family and their doings unjust

You would expect this documentary to be very one-sided, but instead you get two sides battling each other- although it's subtle in the documentary, it's something that is actually happening in real life in the Philippines even up to today
It was clear that Imelda was trying to paint this picture-perfect image of herself to the audience
She repeatedly states that she lost her mother and that she believes she is the mother of the Philippines and that she "birthed" all these great and beautiful things, my only question is: where
Throughout the film I could feel nothing but indecencies coming out of her mouth

I firmly believe in "actions speak louder than words" and there's one scene in the whole documentary that really stood out to me- the scene where Imelda picks up the frame and the other frames fall on the floor

She acts as if nothing happened, she does not even acknowledge, and she goes on and talks about the picture frame she's holding as a worker of her shyly cleans up the broken pieces of glass on the floor

This scene is really interesting as she says all these good things about herself and all yet a small act such as recognizing the frames falling and seeing the worker clean up after her she cannot acknowledge and help

This is very reminiscent of her as a first lady and the Marcos Family- they see what they want and they get it without hesitation, complete unaware of the mess they left behind for the Filipinos to clean up

In addition, throughout the film she mentions that throughout her reign as first lady, she was friends with powerful people all across the globe, further proving how unaware she is of her and herhusband’s doings

She states that she is disgusted with how the government and Philippines is now however she is completely delusional as she doesn’t realize that her and her family has contributed to how the Philippines is no longer “paradise”
Lastly, it’s interesting how this film was made by someone that is not a Filipino

I’m not sure why someone who has no close ties to the Philippines would make a documentary about something so notorious, however, perhaps the fact that it’s so notorious is probably the reason why it was made by the director in the first place
I wondered why no one in the Philippines has made something like this- is it because we are scared of the consequences
Is it because it would be full of bias
Whatever the reason is, I think that the fact this film was made by someone looking at the outside in really gives us a non-biased and equal perspective, as well as a clear division on fact and truth

My gripe with this documentary is how it felt that it shifted to Duterte and that it meandered from Imelda and the main topic on hand, however, I can't really rule this out as the documentary was stating facts and the fact about the Marcos' funding Duterte was vital for people to know
This film was a beautiful yet disturbing layout of Philippine History
Everything was presented in a way that would benefit the feeling and mood of the film

Imelda may have thought that this film would bring her and her family justice, however personally, it just justified why the Philippines and its people are having hardships today
Cheers to Lauren Greenfield and her team for doing a fantastic job

Disclaimer: This is gonna get political due to the fact that I am anti-Marcos and have strong sentiments against dictatorship and media censorship
The Marcos regime has remain to be the most controversial administration in the Philippines
Not only for the numerous allegations and charges that they face, but also for the parade of affluence and wealth of their family
As per the records of anti-corruption agencies, their family has been accused of corruption, violation of human rights, and just recently, perpetration of fake news
Corruption is heavily evident and prevalent in the country
From the local sectors to the national government, it is known to be the root cause of poverty, crime and poor education system
During the Marcos administration, it has been reported that the amount of their so-called ‘ill-gotten wealth’ amount to billions worth of US dollars
In this documentary, they showed some of the acquired properties given to Imelda by his late husband, whom she claimed to be generous for procuring the overseas assets from his hard-earned money
He showered her with innumerable luxurious jewelries and glamorous clothing; All throughout their ruling, Imelda lived like a queen
Hence, the obscene lifestyle and wealth enabled the dictator to extend his presidency and maintain their power that ultimately led to more contentious advances
People power eventually transpired amid chaos fueled by the assassination of Senator Ninoy Aquino; However, it should be noted that it was not the main reason why the resistance emerged

Martial law had been implemented for 8 years – the dark times in Philippine history when human rights and freedom of speech were unheard of - in response to burgeoning hostility that place their throne under threat
Some of the victims, who were mostly activists, spoke of their personal accounts of torture and sexual harassment inflicted onto them by the military/police officials
There were approximately 35,000 Filipinos who went through the same traumatizing experience for speaking out against the misconducts of the government
Opposition groups were silenced, and the media was shutdown
The only voice ever allowed to be heard was from the Conjugal leaders whose reign finally ended after the historic revolution
Until now, the country’s perception of the Marcoses is considerably divided due to the propaganda planted to uphold the legacy of their family name
Despite the charges against them, they still cling onto their false conviction of being trustworthy and country-loving officials as the piles of papers become obsolete edifices

The agencies that are tasked to investigate their family failed to bring them to court and make them admit to their blatant wrongdoings, which is saddening on my end as it’s been ages since the bloody dictatorship took place
Nonetheless, the dark turn of events in the past in relation to the Marcoses’ political careers did not halt the desire to make Malacañang their home once again
In 2016, Bong Bong Marcos, ran for the elections to become Vice President but was greeted by a narrow defeat by Leni Robredo
Since then, he has been attempting to prove that the incumbent VP cheated the elections and thwarted his ascendancy to the position for their contrasting political parties
He had to come up with a plan to gain support from the people and resort to the most accessible propaganda machine: social media
Based on the data gathered from Cambridge Analytica, President Duterte and Bong Bong Marcos are the biggest users of trolls for spreading fake news particularly on Facebook in the Philippines
In my opinion, the administration of Marcos has put the Philippines on the line
Never again to Martial Law
Never again to the dreary cycle of fraudulent conduct, abuse of power, and proliferation of revisionists that are bound to resurface as these unlawful acts are deeply ingrained in their name
Political dynasties ruin the foundation of governance and neglect the needs of the Filipino citizens in favor of their personal interests
Thus, the only way to elude the same fate is to hold the perpetrators accountable and never ever elect them again

This is a really great documentary
On the surface it is a film about the controversial former first lady of the Philippines Imelda Marcos
In reality, though, this film is about something much deeper, an inside look at the troubling dynastic political landscape of the Southeast Asian country
The Marcos presidency was one marked by scandal, corruption, and crime
The film allows Marcos to provide her version of events, her side of the story, but Lauren Greenfield is too smart a filmmaker to allow Marcos to control the narrative
Greenfield is brilliant in how she sets up her scenes, including moments before and after a given 'take' that showcase and highlight Marcos' narcissism and penchant for self indulgence
Greenfield also provides contrasting points of view, footage that provides context, background, and that conflicts with and juxtaposes the words Imelda Marcos spews

This is a woman whose control and corruption are well known and documented, and Greenfield, a director who makes films about the rich and powerful without glorifying their lifestyles but in fact showcasing everything wrong with them, is the person to tell this story

Eventually the film shifts from being a biodoc on Marcus to the current political landscape in the Philippines, Marcos pushing her son to run for president, and the corrupt state of the Filipino political world and how power is constantly transferred between members of the same few families and how little it has to do with the good of the people, who do not factor in at all with the story, they're not even backdrop for the rich, powerful, and influential, and Greenfield makes this abundantly clear
For the Marcos family, and anyone else running the country, it is all about power, wealth, and notoriety and nothing else

Their aspirations are as vacuous as their sense of taste - they accumulate so much, but ultimately all they have to show for it is a lifetime of horrific behavior, crimes against humanity, and a dark soul and evil heart
Bravo Greenfield
This is how you make a doc about someone and make it mean something
i cant believe a whole country had to suffer (and continues to suffer) because imelda had mommy issues

Unfortunately, it’s also about how her family, who has stolen billions that the country is still trying to repay, has slowly returned to power
The Kingmaker never clearly states who is telling the truth
It just shows you Imelda Marcos’ account of events during the Marcos dictatorship, then pits that account against what everyone else is saying
The stories of the experiences of Martial Law victims are particularly heartbreaking, but it doesn’t end there

Just as heartbreaking are scenes where current students in a Metro Manila high school are asked about what happened during Martial Law, and their answers range from “our country’s golden age” to “there was peace and order
” And now Imelda is a member of Congress, Imee is a Senator, and Bongbong was a few hundred thousand votes away from being Vice President
The docu is not without its shortcomings, but more people need to see this
Because they need to know
Because we must never forget
We must also never forget that Sandro Marcos shaded two presidents on his ballot in 2016

Documentary filmmaker Lauren Greenfield established with THE QUEEN OF VERSAILLES a talent for digging into and laying bare how the obscenely wealthy will stop at nothing in the pursuit for luxurious, expensive goods that make them feel validated in their gilded bubble of privilege

With THE KINGMAKER, Greenfield extends her fascination with this habitual overindulgence to the realm of politics, where a rich person's gluttonous spending and consuming means that money is being denied to a whole lot of people whose welfare the rich person is ostensibly meant to care for

Former First Lady of the Philippines Imelda Marcos is the focus of Greenfield's probing, involving study of despotic decadence, and when we're given a glimpse of a closet housing Marcos' 1,000+ pairs of nice shoes, it's pretty impossible as an American viewer not to think of how our current President once counted a solid gold toilet as one of his prized possessions

As an interview subject, Marcos is more shrewd at polite evasions and even-tempered rationalizations than Trump ever has been, so Greenfield's interviews with Filipino activists, former political prisoners, and other residents end up being more illuminating than her sit-downs with the woman at the film's center
But while the lack of hugely revealing soundbites from Marcos is a flaw of this solid documentary, it's not one that Greenfield should realistically shoulder the blame for

If non-fiction filmmakers focusing on politics were expected to find and interview only wealth-hoarding rulers who are as rivetingly dumb and vicious as Trump is, it's likely they'd never get any work done
Lauren Greenfield makes some of the most compelling displays of ego and wealth in documentary cinema
Imelda Marcos is easily the most ambitious target that’s been focused on the opposite end of her camera’s lens
The first couple of minutes, I thought I was essentially watching ‘Queen of Versailles’ again, but set in the Philippines

Especially when we have clips of Marcos handing children dollar bills from the side of her car to the poor citizens of Manilla, and an extended moment of Marcos boast about a photograph in her courtyard while ignoring a bunch of broken picture frames she knocked over getting quietly cleaned up by the Help
But the truth is slowly dripped out, and the film shows a much less “ignorant” and “vain” version of this person, but one that is much more insidious and corrupt

In The Kingmaker, we see explore this through the Marcos regime and its aftermath (and perhaps future)
We see Imelda sitting in her apartment, surrounded by the riches and the beauty she always seems to strive for
Some can probably note the piece behind her as something in the style of Picasso, and yes, it is definitely a Picasso
She even proudly confirms this herself
Imelda has a way with words
She interweaves her personal stories with sentiment, nostalgia, and this whole schtick with maternity (I'll get to that later)
It's as sugar-coated as it is convincing, especially if you don't know much about the Marcos family or if your Filipino history game is a bit lacking
Outsiders who are out of the loop may sympathise, and the Filipino viewers -- most of who are tired and weary -- may even be captivated by her through their last shred of hope
But this is where it gets good
I really like how Greenfield lets Imelda talk, then juxtaposes it with accounts from multiple people
The selection was very interesting, with the roster including people who sympathise with -- and fought against --the Marcos regime back in those days
It even includes people who are currently in office (at least during the time of this review)
Then suddenly you, the viewer, realise that Imelda's words are like a house of cards
My favourite example of this is Calauit Island, where Greenfield not only tells but shows exactly what exactly it had done to both the animals and people who lived there decades later
This style of show-and-perhaps-contradict repeats throughout the documentary, and Greenfield lets it all speak for itself
You, the viewer, doesn't really have to be told outright that Imelda is a narcissist: it just comes out
She tries to hide it around this whole thing about how she is the, and I loosely quote, "mother of the world"
That it perfectly justifies the reason why her son should be in power, and how they were actually doing a good thing (this includes her husband's regime)

But through the help of the accounts of others, The Kingmaker paints a disturbingly beautiful picture created by the brushstrokes of horror, pain, and struggle that trickles down even in modern Filipino society
While Imelda sits in places of extravagance, and The Kingmaker, does not hesitate in making us remember where exactly all that money came from

The Kingmaker is a 2019 documentary film written and directed by Lauren Greenfield, featuring the political career of Imelda Marcos with a focus on the Marcos family's efforts to rehabilitate the family's image and to return to political power, including her plans to see her son Bongbong become President of the Philippines, and the alliance that Bongbong and Imee Marcos established with Rodrigo Duterte in his bid to win the 2016 Philippine presidential election
This documentary lays bare the vile nature of the political strategies deployed by the Marcos family
Ferdinand Marcos is deservedly portrayed as a fascist capitalist dictator
But their greed and lust or power does not stop there
After Ferdinand dies and is denied a funeral in the Philippines, they deploy covert secret strategic tactics to regain power, status and regain their former political reign
They abuse social media to spread lies, use smear campaigns to get back their political power, kill power, oust people who intervene in their plans
The list of vile crimes is endless
I was shocked by the fact that the Philippine people still believed in the Marcos family even after Ferdinand Marcos had 30
000 people killed
For some unknown reason they still vote for Imee Marcos, Ferdinand's daughter, and later on even for Bong Bong, Ferdinand's son
Thd most vile betrayal is the political ruse of letting the people believe that Duterte is a better option than Imelda Marcos
In actuality the Marcos family had struck a deal with Duterte, a former minister in Marcos' government, for the mere purpose of letting Duterte become president
Once Duterte becomes president he removes all those who do not agree with Marcos' views
Duterte when inaugurated acts just like his former co-conspirator Ferdinand Marcos
Hence he kills people
and keeps the people in check by oppression
Duterte even abolishes the PCGG, the committee which works towards getting all the money stolen by Marcos
The leader of the PCGG is charged with corruption and fraud
Similar action are taken against the vice president Robredo
At present, Duterte has imprisoned most people who oppose Marcos
Furthermore, Imee has become a senator in the northern region of the Philippines
Duterte, and the Marcos family are now working towards having Bong Bong inaugurated as the new president of the Philippines
So the evil of the Marcos family is about start all over again
A ridiculously intimate view into the life of Imelda Marcos and the legacy she has left behind

It’s unthinkable how power concentrated in the hands of two people—herself and her husband, back when he was still President—could rip apart the lives of millions, but this documentary leaves no stone unturned in its unflinching exploration of history as shaped by them
The first half of the documentary is laughable, satirical almost, as one listens to Imelda’s own retelling of past events, perfected to a crisp with rehearsed smoothness

But the second half is a punch in the stomach, once Greenfield pieces together various stories regarding the political scene in the Philippines to flesh out a portrait of greed, corruption, lavishness and cruelty that now runs through generations
Not only do the effects of the Marcos regime still reverberate deeply through the country today, it feels almost as if they have never left with their relentless quest to return to power
The photography is straightforward but agile; the editing simple but powerful; the soundtrack eerie but compelling
Put together, there cannot be a title more aptly descriptive about the rise (and fall and rise again) of Imelda than “The Kingmaker”

Although unique from each other, the message is the same with the strong contemporary documentaries released within the first years of President Duterte’s administration such as A Thousand Cuts and Aswang

Compared with the two however, Lauren Greenfield’s film is more well-edited, hinting parallelisms from the past Marcos administration with the current government, making Imelda Marcos as the bridge that kept filling the gap between the two
Grandiose and almost royal in manner, I see Imelda in a two-headed monster having one neck that is filled of delusions of grandeur
The monster’s other head died, and as the head was cut off and laid unfortunately to rest amongst the honorables, one head continues to rise
And with these heads, a neck kept on and keeps on turning these heads to serve their own selfish purpose
This ardent and repugnantly wide neck is Imelda herself
Being true to her brand, Imelda blatantly shows wealth, which is a manifestation of her own understanding of beauty and love

But hidden beneath her clamor were the suffering of many Filipinos: from the residents of Calauit island to the murder and rape victims of Martial Law and to all the Filipinos, to whom the Marcoses are still accountable for
She stood by Ferdinand Marcos dictatorial rule and she’s standing by Bongbong’s political route to power
The rise and fall and their rising again feels like that Filipinos are inside a horror movie wherein it doesn’t matter how many times you kill the monster
Rest assured that after the end credits, a resurrection will be shown, which will birth a series of never-ending sequels
A truly scary state for an already aching country, a disease-stricken country
With our body there are lots of checks and balances that maintain homeostasis
Likened to a well-oiled machine, it is very organized up to a certain point wherein a harmful external factor can damage the whole organism
With my country, it seems that there’s a gradual reversal of this homeostasis
Slowly creeping in in the very own checks and balances of this country’s institutions
And without recognition from its own members, it will persist, continually making the whole country sick and killing its people one by one until there are no more Filipinos worth dying for
As a healer by profession, I tend to the sick
And whenever I encounter patients who I know have a lower chance of survival, wherein limitations of science and the practice of medicine are fully exhausted, it eats me to the core
There is so much that I can do to save a life, but one can’t save them all
The same feeling of hopelessness is what I feel with my country
A dim reflection I know, but by not stating this singular groan from a citizen, societal problems will not be recognized
And with this film it serves this purpose: recalling the past, stating the present and heeding a warning for the future

When I was 8 years old, I remember my father brought a CD of Imelda (2003) when he came home from work in Manila
I had a vague memory of me watching this film on TV, together with my family, when Netflix or any streaming services weren't concepted yet

Little did I know that beyond the tapestry of all Imelda's extravagant furniture and her infamous 3,000 pair of shoe collection shown in the film, is a lady who stood by a tyrant and a dictator, who's ill-gotten wealth is being paid off by the Filipino people up to this very moment
What's even more baffling is the fact that in The Kingmaker, Imelda claims that the era of Martial Law in the Philippines upheld "sovereignty, freedom, justice, and human rights" in our country
Excuse me, Ma'am
Last time I checked, the Martial Law era perpetuated exactly the opposites of what you claimed--it was the darkest and most brutal time in the Philippines
Journalists were executed, activists were tortured and arrested, and newspaper outlets were silenced
I am outraged
It saddens me how students here define Marcos' era as being peaceful and disciplined, as per reflected in the documentary
It's as though all extrajudicial killings, arrests, and tortures never even took place
I really hope colleges would mandatorily employ Martial law studies in order to revisit the past, and scrutinize where things have gone wrong
I'm glad how this documentary also pointed out the current Duterte Administration
Vis-a-vis Marcos' era as a point of reference, I could enunciate a number of similarities between their presidencies
It's like reliving the past and the horrors all over again
God bless the Philippines
Catch me on the road to Mars whenever time permits so

Weathering the storm that is Imelda Marcos is difficult, deadly even
However, Lauren Greenfield's haunting documentary The Kingmaker proves that one can dance with the devil
The film examines the lives of the Marcos clan from their rise to the Philippine government, their downfall, and their eventual return to their current political endeavors

To those unfamiliar with their name, the presidency of Ferdinand Marcos (1965 to 1986) caused some of the worst human rights violations seen in Philippine history, not to mention how the oppressive regime plunged the country's economy
While the film's title is appropriate because of its masterful storytelling, the documentary's main subjects are not worthy of this royal embellishment
Greenfield wastes no time in depicting the dichotomy between Imelda and the everyday Filipino citizen
Its first scene illustrates how emotionless she is when she hands out 50s to the beggars, proceeding to call their area "depressing" after reflecting on her loss of power
This opening scene already sets Imelda as someone immaculate, a savior or—in her words—a "mother" to those who are in need of her love
But as the film proceeds, we see how the Marcoses were never the loving parents every child wanted; their names continue haunt the people who were tortured and killed during Martial Law
The Kingmaker beautifully interpolates many sides of those who lived during and beyond the Marcos dictatorship
It is this multisectoral approach that helps audiences understand how grave the consequences of Martial Law really are
From Imelda's friends to opposition figures and Martial Law victims and activists, no stone is left unturned in dissecting how Imelda's brain works
What took the cake for me was how these figures were visited a few years after

For example, Vice President Leni Robredo and activist May Rodriguez' thoughts regarding Bongbong Marcos' vice presidential run were cut into two—the time leading up to the 2016 elections and the aftermath of Robredo's win
This follow up emphasizes how the Marcoses' dirt will never be erased from history, despite their numerous attempts to do so
It feels like the country hasn't moved much in terms of progression
What's more haunting is that all the imagery of Marcos running feels familiar, scarily real even
Now that Marcos is vouching for President, it is deeply concerning how far their influence can go
This is what exactly The Kingmaker aims to address: to expose the shoes and skeletons of the Marcos family's closets and to remind Filipinos of their oppressive rule
It demonstrates how far one will go to sustain their wealth, power, and image
Time will tell when the Marcos magic will finally disappear from the country
But for now, let this film be a reminder to never forget the many lives that suffered under their brutal rule
